description: Great neighborhood market with an outstanding deli making first rate sandwiches, including what they call, their "world famous turkey", freshly carved. The market is fairly small and closes early.
author: Clayton D.

description:
I had a really unpleasant experience at Arguello Market recently. I went in on a Monday around 9:30 a.m.​ to grab some of their ​turkey sandwiches and some coffee. First I go to the deli. I am literally the only person in the entire store other than the employees and the gent at the counter makes me wait 5 minutes. No 'hello I'll be right with you,' not even a nod just busy work. Finally,​ he looks at me and nods and I ask for 3 turkey sandwiches. Again, no greeting/how can I help you just barely a blink and starts working. 

I go grab some self-serve coffees. To save a minute I tell the lady at the cash register I am getting 3 turkey sandwiches and two coffees, can you please charge me? "Nope,​ I have to scan them first." O,​k that's a bit silly as they are obviously already coded in the cash register but I'll wait. Again. I am still the only customer in the entire store now. 

Finally from the deli man, "sandwiches done!" No thank you, no nothing, just the bag of sandwiches left on the counter. Ok I'm fine you're having a bad morning, I get it. 

I return over to the cashier lady with my bag of 3 identical sandwiches. I pull one out and say here we go charge me for this times 3 and we're all set. Nope,​ she doesn't trust/believe me that it's 3 of the same sandwiches even though she's literally 10 feet away from the deli counter and has had nothing to do but watch this whole thing unfold. She proceeds to dump all of the sandwiches out of the bag and scan each individually​ as if to say I don't believe you dude and you're not getting any freebies from me. Again, no 'thanks/have a nice day' not even a 'go eff yourself...'

I pay and hit the road wondering if perhaps there was a hostage situation in-progress in Arguello Market I just interrupted. Because failing that, I can think of no logical reason why I was treated with such neglect, mistrust, and contempt. I love to support the local grocery store but I am not planning to come back to Arguello anytime soon unless it's for an emergency. There are literally 5 or 6 other grocery stores within a five-minute​ drive. So just wow Arguello, get your act together. Treat the customer with decency or just get out of business...
author: Noah K.

description:
This market has been written up so many times for their "famous fresh turkey sandwich". Finally, I had to try it.
Huge deli counter with lots of foodie choices, but I had my eye on that turkey sandwich. The place can get pretty busy (at the deli that is) and there was only 1 person greeting and making sandwiches, so it was about 15 min. before I could order mine. Only 4 people ahead of me.
All things considered, the turkey itself was moist and very flavorful. No fat, which was really nice. The sandwich consisted of both white and dark meat. I chose a sourdough bread instead of the dutch crunch (easier for me to eat). Min price for sandwich w/o anything extra is $7.99. I added cheese and cranberry, bringing the price to $9.99. 
There is an abundance of turkey on the sandwich, but everything and I mean everything is piled in the middle, leaving the perimeter of the sandwich just bread. Because of this, I won't be returning. The price is a tad "steep" for me, but this seems to be the going rate these days.
Though other markets make an equally good (if not better turkey sandwich) for about 2 bucks less. Oh and they too use fresh turkey.
But I had to try it.
author: Marla B.

description:
The only reasons you should shop here is for convenience and supporting local businesses. It's a cute market with decent options for groceries, but it's pretty expensive. If you're a fan of supporting local businesses and don't mind paying extra for your monthly groceries budget, I'd say shop here. There's also Safeway and Lucky's which are all fairly close to Arguello Market which are more affordable and have better variety.

P.S. the manager looks like he wants everyone dead and it's not very welcoming in the slightest.
author: Amy N.

description: Overhyped sandwich, the quality wasn't there for me. I got the famous turkey sandwich and had fat and skin pieces in it which really turned me off. I thought the sandwich was dry
author: Christina M.

description: All Dark Meat Turkey Sandwich?  I was hankering for a solid turkey sandwich and I was in the area of the Arguello market.  They are "known"  for their turkey sandwich.  No line, I ordered mine and went off to get some other items - great store BTW.  I come back the sandwich is ready and I check out and drive to a spot in the Presidio where I am gong to savor the sandwich.  Wrong answer.  It was all dark meat.  Who makes an all dark meat turkey sandwich without asking or saying - "hey all we have left is dark meat - are you cool with this???"  Nope.  The bread, mayo  and onion and tomato were good....
author: Emmett Q.

description: I love it when places say their thing is world famous when it almost definitely isn't. Their turkey sandwich is billed as such and I'm pretty skeptical that it's been recognized in many other countries, or frankly even SF neighborhoods. But it's a good sandwich! The turkey is remarkably moist. The dutch crunch they use could have a little bit more bite though.
author: Misha T.

description: This market is extremely overpriced. It is business is probably only from its surrounding neighbors who are either willing to spend extra money or too lazy to go to another market. It is a small local business, and it does have almost everything that you need there. The interior is very clean and neat. They also have a deli, but the food is just mediocre for its price.
author: Kaylee P.

description:
Was it me?  Read about their highly rated roast turkey sandwich so thought I check it out as I was in the area. I walked in.  The deli is to the left. It's got high deli counters.  And I'm petite.  I saw a deli worker with his back to me. I get his attention by saying "hi".  He turns around and snaps at me.  "I'm working on a sandwich".  And turns his back on me.  I'm taken back by his rudeness.  Should I shake it off?   I wait several seconds.  Then I say there's no excuse for that.  I leave without ordering.  

I'm disappointed.  No sandwich.
author: Shirley N.

description:
In today's economy safety and efficient spending of money is without a doubt a number uno.
I use my credit card and try to limit the amount of cash I hold on my person. When I walk into stores as this one, that ask for a five dollar minimum to make a purchase it makes it hard to want to repeat business there especially if most items are under 5.
I came in to buy a simple candy bar and realize that the surcharge is beginning to become an issue with not only mom-and-pop liquor stores but now it is affecting local markets as they are putting a surcharge and or minimum purchase limit for items to boost sales.
This is illegal and I plan on doing something with. it is not fair to the people to be charge more when they are simply trying to pay and get on with the day.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
This is a cool grocery store/restaurant.  The atmosphere is laid back and you get the feeling that they have "regulars" that order the same sandwich all the time.  Seems like a family feel when you go in.  My 3 star review is not for the store necessarily but more for the sandwich and soup.  

I had a turkey sandwich on white with avocado and cheddar cheese. It was a $10-11 sandwich.  

It was okay. Nothing to write home about.  

I also had the turkey chili. It was hot and delicious. But again nothing to write home about. 

Generally, I probably would eat here again but I wouldn't go out of my way to return.
author: Karla J.

description:
Great sandwiches , only thing you guys might wanna communicate to your deli team that there are spanish speaking customers that understand what is being said about them. 
Making fun of people will not get you more business 
what a shame, they really do have good sandwiches
author: Mario S.

description: We live in the neighborhood and shop at Arguello a lot during the week. It is very convenient as you can find good quality products, including a good range of organic products and, in my experience, is cheaper than some of the other larger stores in the area. The staff is very professional and helpful and will order an item if unavailable.
author: Angela D.

description:
Very nice\ upscale neighborhood market. Has everything you need in a pinch and more.
Good produce section.
Nice deli with sandwiches 
Decent alcohol selection
It's a bit pricey but that's expected 
I would recommend this market to anyone that lives in the neighborhood. It's very convenient!
author: Kevin S.

description:
I would like to support small businesses, but the market has a substantial markup compared to your average supermarket. If I were in the neighborhood and needed to pick something up, Arguello Super Market would be a great option. For my normal grocery needs, I'll stick to the usual suspects.
Now, the turkey sandwich at the deli counter has been recommended to me many times, so I gave it a try. The Dutch Crunch was excellent, of course. It would have been better if the sandwich was toasted. Cold turkey and cold cheese wasn't great. 
There are a couple of small tables outside, so that's convenient. In fact, this quaint little market and deli provides all the convenience anyone in this neighborhood needs food-wise.
author: Joy W.

description:
Hey Arguello Super Market, 

Just sending a quick note to thank you for helping us out with the purchase of our Muni Passports* while we visit San Fran.   Your store is charming and your staff was just the nicest.  Even your manager came over to say 'hello' while we checked out.  Next time we're in town maybe we'll stop back to try one of your turkey sandwiches... rumor has it they're pretty amazing. 

Until then, 
Alyssa P.


* The store sells the 1-Day Visitor Passport, 3-Day Visitor Passport, and 7-Day Visitor Passport.  Note: cash or debit only for the Muni Passports.
author: Alyssa R.

description:
Overhyped sandwich place. How did I end up spending $13 on a sandwich? Nothing really to write home about but it's in a good location. If you're planning a day out in Golden Gate Park this would be an ideal spot to get a nice sandwich. 

Got a turkey sandwich with cran and cheese on Dutch crunch. The guy didn't ask if I wanted it toasted so as I unwrapped my sandwich it was very anti climactic for me. turkey was dry (cranberry helps!) and I've definitely had better. Good but not amazing. Their produce seem very overpriced.
author: Jodie L.

description: 2 words: ROTISSERIE TURKEY. Classic combo with cranberry sauce on dutch crutch is the best around.
author: Becca A.

description:
***they roast their own turkeys for sandwiches*** 

The meat is tender and moist and you have a choice of white or dark meat. *YAS* 

I would come here when I was in grad school at USF. Quick walk during our lunch breaks on Saturdays. Great community market, good size and very fresh products. Delicious fresh turkey sandwiches! 

The sammies were super well priced (at the time), prices may have gone up since then. 

Must try adding avocado and cranberry sauce!
author: Rena J.

description:
Ordered a sandwich earlier this evening. Guy making the sandwich was really nasty. Acted like he was doing me a favor. When I paid, he was as nasty as when he made the sandwich. I said thank you and reciprocally, I recieved a blank stare.  So far, so good. 

Went home to eat and have to say the Turkey sandwich was disgusting. It literally contained scraps of dark meat and a few pieces of white meat. 

From the dispicalble service, to the absolutely horrifying sandwich, needless to say I won't ever be back.

They made sure of it.
author: michael l.

description: The deli counter staff and young cashiers are very nice, but my experience with the manager left little to be desired. I came back to return a jar of cherry juice, with my receipt included, when I realized it was a juice blend and not 100% cherry juice.  The young lady at the counter said, but it's 100% juice so what's the issue?  She called in her supervisor over who rolled his eyes at me, and said if you're going to return something bring it to the counter before you start shopping, and then proceeded to give me the stare down like I wronged him in some way.  I don't appreciate being made to feel like I've shoplifted to return a product, and as a small locally owned supermarket I would expect better service than the usual Safeway.  Mind you, I was nicely dressed and didn't roll out of bed bumming it when I stopped in.  I don't plan to come back. Go to safeway on 7th and cabrillo instead
author: Joyce T.

description:
The need for greeting a customer upon eye contact is necessary.  Ie, "hello, we'll be right with you"...  common courtesy/ manners 
Smooches
author: niki p.

description: Not bad - I couldn't make up my mind on which sandwich to get so I ended up with a classic roasted turkey sandwich. Nothing really stood out to me besides the fact it was a warm, and I could tell it was fresh. Turkey meat is hard to please. Maybe I'll request to add more fillers next time. It took about 7-10 minutes until my order was ready which isn't bad given the number of people that were waiting in line. Customer service is alright. I guess this is your ol' average market and deli.
author: Chris D.

description:
This is for the deli only. I like the market.
Mr sandwich makers- these guys never listen 
And kinda suck. I know making sandwiches all day sucks, I've done it. BUT it's the job. 
Wouldn't hurt to appreciate customers either and just listen to the order and don't argue back when it's wrong - which is 50% of the time. 

If it was  it for your perfect roast turkey
Your average as hell.
author: Michael H.

description: Contrary to the information here, they do have Apple Pay. Like everyone else, I love the turkey sandwich. And you can get practically anything else here in a pinch. Pliers, candles, whatever. The stock is wide and varied.
author: Steve T.

description:
I usually go there for the Roasted turkey sandwich because the turkeys are roasted on site every day.     

Today I order turkey soup and the roasted pepper soup.  If you are a soup freak like me you love this place.
author: Dennis W.

description:
Despicable! This business is a disgrace to this community. For this I cannot recommend that anyone reward them with their patronage. They are heartless, pathetic and cruel. They do not deserve to serve this wonderful city or neighborhood.

I should not have to reveal this, but I feel that it is important to note because it is a critical detail to my experience. I am a Type 1 diabetic with an insulin pump (for those who do not know it is a life-saving device that is permanently attached to my body to release insulin -- required to sustain my life). The device does not usually cause me any problems, but every once in a while I have a need to address an issue with the device. 

I stopped in here on Sunday, September 3 to grab a few groceries. I'd jumped off the 5-Fulton to do some shopping on my way home. I shop here every so often... or at least I used to. I would stop in quickly, grab a few things, and then catch the next bus down Fulton feeling good that I spent my money at a small business. Ha, so much for that.

While in the store, I realized I had an issue with my pump that I knew I needed to deal with quickly. I asked to use their restroom so that I could figure out the problem (which required me to remove my top, so I needed a bit of privacy). I explained this to the female clerk, but she was not having it. She was rude, rude, RUDE! There was another customer that overheard the conversation and was like "Are you seriously not going to let her use the bathroom?". Nope, they were not.

Like, this could turn into a medical emergency. But they could not care less. Like, I get it, we are in the city and public toilets are not a thing, but this is a life-sustaining device with an error. Would they rather have an ambulance come get me?  Yes, apparently they would. F*ckers.

The other customer was nice enough to jump into action, offered me a quick ride to the Safeway a few blocks away who DID let me use the bathroom to fix the tubing on my pump before the situation became critical (thank you Lydia!). We both grabbed what we needed from Safeway and went our separate ways.

So yeah. This store lost me as a customer and I will not ever be shopping there again. As much as it pains me to say it, I'll be much more inclined to shop at Safeway knowing that they have my back if I need them. 

SO yeah, screw you, "Arguello Super Market".  Screw. You.
author: May L.

description:
This is a review for just the deli.

A staple sandwich place of the inner richmond.  I am a fan but I can agree it is a little pricey for a sandwich.

A couple of things to take note of:

-Average price of a sandwich ($10-$12)
-The wait can get longer during lunch (15 minutes at the most)
- My personal favorites are the prosciutto and turkey
author: Anthony B.

description: Great neighborhood market. Deli selection of prepared foods is solid, and the roast turkey sandwich is second to none. Friendly and helpful staff, and ample outdoor seating.
author: Garrett K.

description:
Though the food is ok, the service is far from decent. Coming in with high expectations I assumed this place would have both great food and great service. Neither were true. My girlfriend went for the first time about a month ago per my recommendation, and she said the service was bad and the sandwich order was wrong. Believing this place was great I assumed it was a one-time thing. 

I went today to see if her initial impression was misplaced.  However her initial impression was confirmed.  I went with my sister and we each ordered a sandwich.  Place was not busy only two other customers.  Staff was rude. Her order was correct.  Mine was not.  Simple sandwich with cheese and no tomato. Frustrating.
author: Jeffrey G.

description:
The Arguello market is a very mixed bag of some tasty things and some overpriced things. 

What's good and cheap? Pre made Wraps, and the piroshki's. 

What's in the middle? Sandwiches and the lunch boxes. Lunch boxes are priced well but not amazingly at $12 for a sandwich + a lot of goodies. The sandwiches are kinda dry; I like to take them home and add sauce. You can substitute tastier salad into the lunch boxes for only $1. The Mac and cheese was mediocre, but the Chinese chicken salad hit the spot. 

What's priced badly? OJ, or the salads if you just buy them. 

I'd come back cause it's convenient, but it just isn't amazing enough to recommend.
author: Chris S.

description: Very disappointed in the Dutch Crunch. It was stale and disgusting and their sandwiches are not cheap!! $30 for three sandwiches. Won't go there again -- waste of money. Very sad
author: Corrine C.

description:
Okay I just don't understand why this place seem to always run out of sweet rolls to make a sandwich. At this point I think they just say they don't have it to watch me walk out. Today I was waiting while the one person behind the counter was doing something. Then the next customer said I'd like a sandwich on a sweet roll. The person behind the counter said Oh we are out. Then I turned to walk out and another worker that has seem me leave many times when they don't have sweet rolls for a sandwich just gives me this look like ha ha ha no sandwich of you.

The last time I told myself I would stop trying but today was such a warm day I thought a sandwich would be great. It was...I went down to Safeway and got one for less money and less attitude.
author: John C.

description:
Arguello market, grocery wise, has most things you need but it's a bit pricey. I usually go here for their famous turkey sandwiches. Hands down one of the best turkey sandwiches you can get in the city and its very fresh with mixed of dark and white meat. 

I usually get it with a dutch crunch roll with everything on it and extra cranberry sauce and avocados! Yum!
author: Jenn L.

description: The staff and management are great - it's the deli puts Arguello Market over the top.  I've been coming here for 5 years as a resident of the neighborhood for groceries on a weekly basis.  I recently learned that they have gluten free bread for the world-famous turkey sandwich, so I can enjoy one too. There's not a better sandwich in SF for the price, hands down.  If you can eat regular bread get the dutch crunch!
author: Carl R.

description: All I've really gotten from here is the hot turkey sandwich, but it is legit. They have a rotisserie and cook actual turkeys and then carve those for the sandwich. I mean, you can also get cold cut sandwich, but why? I get mine with cranberry sauce. Its like the day after thanksgiving, any day of the year. Parking also isn't that bad, which was originally a surprise.
author: Michael K.

description:
World famous turkey sandwich? Famous for what? Dry turkey, dry bread, dry ingredients? A few warm pieces of turkey into an otherwise cold sandwich does not a hot sandwich make. 

Suggestions to make this a real world famous sandwich:
1. Heat it up. Press it, grill it, do something with the bread.
2. Add moistness. Slather on something interesting besides mayo. Flavored mayo would be fine even. Other ideas include dips, hummus, oil spreads.
3. Add tang. Mustard is usually fine, but not the amount you put on. Add some pickles, or other pickled ingredients.
4. More tomatoes. Can't go wrong here. Plus, they add moisture and tang.

Let me know if you're up for the challenge, and I'll be happy to return.
author: Andrew R.

description:
This is a rating on the famous turkey sandwich, because I don't really think you need me to rate the produce. I ordered the turkey on the dutch crunch at around 1 PM on a Tuesday. There were already some other people in life before us, but it definitely took less time to get a sandwich here than it would at Lou's or one of the other nearby Richmond sandwich shops.

So they got my order wrong- which was not the worst thing in the world, because instead of cheese I ended up with avocado. Otherwise, measuring the sandwich based off the turkey, cranberry, and bread. It was a filling sandwich- difficult to finish. But I would not label this the best sandwich in SF. Maybe it is because my dad used to make sandwiches using the pulled meat of a turkey or chicken, that this was not a wow, first time thing for me compared to others who typically only eat sliced turkey. Don't get me wrong, it's an adequate sandwich. I'd come back just because it is less than a block away from where I normally stay, but it would be more so out of convenience than the sandwich's taste. The dutch crunch is sweet which matches well with the cranberry sauce but sometimes it was a little too much for me. The turkey was okay, nothing amazing. 

It's a good sandwich if you're in the area, but nothing you need to travel for.
author: Arezou A.

description:
Theis review is for the supermarket as a whole and it is a very great market. I don't live nearby but if I did, it would definitely be the place I would go and get my groceries. It has the products of a higher end grocery store like Whole Foods, but has that small market/deli feel that you would see in a small town. Their deli is definitely top-of-the-line with excellent deli selections with particular emphasis placed on their potato salads, on which there is at least four or five different varieties.

I should note, however, that the reason I came here is for their roast turkey sandwich, which, if I were giving this review solely based on that sandwich, I would have given three stars. Now, granted, I am more of a fan of extra-thinly-sliced turkey but even with that being said, I really failed to see what gave this sandwich the great recognition that it has received. It was very dry and there was no flavor at all. The funny thing is I was starving and more often than not, even flavorless food can taste good to me when I am really hungry. That wasn't the case here. Honestly, if I didn't have some of their delicious creole potato salad to accompany this sandwich, I would have been less than satisfied with my experience at this place.

That being said, I am judging this place as a whole and I wouldn't mind coming back here for some of their other products and deli selections. I might also give one of their other sandwiches a try in the future if I am in the right mood.
author: Kunal N.

description:
walked past the Deli with the turkey sammie suppossedly best value in the market. had something else on my mind.

nice upscale grocery in the vein of whole foods, maybe as pricey too.

buys: Rasputin stout (6.99)
-solid brew, slightly higher then Bewmo.

take outs:
-service quick, courteious, no lines.
-not a destination. nice local source.....
author: Victor G.

description: I could barely fit it in my mouth! What a large turkey sandwich. I see now why they call it world famous. Real turkey meat out of a grocery store? Seems too good to be true but that's SF for ya. Super tasty and kind workers who are in GO mode. I like it a lot!
author: Samantha J.

description:
My boyfriend and I had just finished hiking the Presidio and were dying for a bite to eat and a place to rest our legs. We'd heard that we had to try a sandwich on Dutch Crunch bread while in SF so we thought this place would make a good lunch stop based on the reviews on Yelp. 

My boyfriend and I both ordered the "famous" fresh roasted turkey sandwich. I agree with all the more recent reviews here that said it was dry and kind of bland because that was how we felt about it too. The turkey did taste fresh, but most of the pieces were from the breast, and it just wasn't that moist, and I'm someone who loves turkey. The parts with dark meat were very nice however. In addition, the sandwich really needed something else in it to take it to the next level. The sandwiches we got only had turkey, lettuce, tomato, a smear of mayo, and two (yes, I counted) pickle slices. No cheese, no avocado, no bacon. The parts with pickle were great, but it needed a lot more than two tiny slices. I will give them credit, the sandwich was large and I was stuffed afterwards, but I could make a much better sandwich at home. I thought the price was fair for the size of the sandwich, but I probably wouldn't come back. The supermarket itself was cute and clean with plenty of seating both inside and outside for people who want to enjoy their sandwiches. It seems to be very popular with locals so maybe we just ordered the wrong sandwich.
author: Katie H.

description:
This review is just for the roast turkey sandwich at the counter. When I showed up on a Sunday at noon and there were 6-7 people ahead of me in line for a sandwich, I had a good feeling. The line moved fast and I ordered 2 roast turkey sandwiches. They had an oven there roasting 2-3 whole turkeys and they slice it fresh right in front of you.

The sandwich was basically the best turkey sandwich I've ever had. Super moist and delicious meat and quality bread (I got dutch crunch).

Plus we ate there outside. Recommended.
author: Jordan C.

description:
I hesitate to write this review because I live a block away and know I will go to Arguello Market at least 2x a week. 
I just hate that I have to go here. To be specific I am reviewing the market and not the deli. 
1. The turkey sandwhich with cranberries is DELICIOUS. I crave this sandwich sometimes and NEED to eat it. It is big, unique, and I am pretty sure it is made with love every time, by some beardy man. Thank you, beardy man!

But if I were to review the market, and offer any advice.  My advice is: plan ahead so that when you go to the normal grocery store: Safeway, trader Joes, or Costco, you buy everything you need at a reasonable price and do not have to come here for the ones offs, which are REALLY expensive. And those one offs add up. I would know.
$10 for one filet of salmon
$10 for  1lb ground coffee
$10 for hot chocolate mix! :(
$5 for almond milk...ok maybe that is normal, but you could by it on sale somewhere!

Maybe other people are made out of money and don't mind paying the convenience premium, but I resent people like my boyfriend who keeps sending me on these one offs that at the end of the week have cost me $50.

Mr. Arguello Market, please do not throw me out of your store when you see me come in.

P.S. That hispanic man that always wears the white uniform and works as a cashier needs an attitude adjustment. The lady cashiers are a delight though!
author: Julianna I.

description: A little expensive for the things in the market, but their sandwiches, made on the spot, are so gooood. The owner is rude, but the sandwiches are worth putting up with the butthead.
author: Josh L.

description:
Hands down the most stingy ownership ever!! Every thing is an extra cost on sandwiches!!  But they don't warn you ahead of time until at the register, you notice an additional $1.50 added to the price of the sandwich.  This is a long standing practice of this market.

Now for the reason why I'm writing about it today.  As I was begrudgingly walking in to grab a drink, I overheard the manager confronting a already paid up customer sitting in front... mid bite into her sandwich, and interrogating her about whether or not her sandwich has cheese on it.  He then informs her, that she now owes an additional dollar for the cheese, which he failed to ring up in the first place.  WTF!! Your mistake, don't up charge customers after they have started eating!  

As I was shocked at that scene I went in and grabbed a couple items.  They added up to $4 bucks and some change.  I'm ready to pay and told $5 dollar minimum for using a card!  Ok, so you don't want my business?  Got it!  I haven't frequented or purchased a sandwich there in a very long time because they have so many extra costs on sandwiches, looks like I won't be frequenting the store anytime soon.  Good luck with continually offending customers.  When they go out of business for lack of customer oriented practices, and losing repeat business, they'll have themselves to blame excessively nickel and diming customers!!
author: M L.

description:
Wanted to mainly check out the sandwiches. I know they are famous for their turkey sandwiches, but that's really not my thing. So tried out their pastrami sandwich and their rotisserie chicken sandwich. I am a big fan of pastrami sandwiches, so I can honestly say that I have had better. The chicken sandwich was also so-so. 

As for the rest of the place, it seems decent, though with a very small selection of fresh fruits and vegetables. I like that they have indoor and outdoor seating however. Overall, a quite nice place to have in the neighborhood.
author: Seema K.

description: Sooooo delicious turkey sandwich. I usually come here buy it since it's near to my home. Must have dutch crunch and everything on it!
author: Maggie T.

description:
Review solely for the sandwiches.

When my boy made it a point to stop here before our trip, I was a bit puzzled. Why are we going to a supermarket? I just returned from Europe and was sick of sandwiches, wraps, and paninis. Please, I thought, no more bread!

But, after standing in line for a good couple minutes and seeing the line build up only for the deli counter, I knew my boy was right.

We got the turkey hot sandwich on Dutch crunch and I got the hot pastrami and Swiss on Dutch crunch. The sandwich was so massive I had to split one half for lunch and the last half for dinner. 

The pastrami was piled so high it was like having a full meatball inside the sandwich. It was freaking heavenly!!! 

Best part of it all? Each sandwich was less than $8 and I'm for sure going back.
author: Leslie L.

description:
we stopped at arguello to pick up sandwiches before a picnic in the park. They messed up my sandwich, mixing my order up with a friends, but it was not a big deal. Their carved turkey is really great as was their bread. I ordered a side of pasta salad; however, and it tasted like a flower. Seriously, we all thought it tasted like lavender. Would not recommend.

The order:
Roasted Turkey Sandwich all toppings (no mustard) with added provolone and avocado- Toasted  - 5
Macaroni Salad - 2
author: Jodi R.

description:
I live in the neighborhood. It was convenient for me. Their sandwiches are okay but mediocre (I've had better).

Two things:
One: Rudeness! This expensive trap all they care about is profit and not their customers. I read one comment here and discovered that they are also homophobic! In San Francisco!? One of their employees in response to my elatedness over the US Supreme Court's decision to strike down DOMA (Defense Of Marriage Act) and to Scalia's disapproval the court passed 5 to 4 the same sex marriage as law of the land in all 50 states! Finally! This twit made the comment to me "You fags should have lost that ruling, Scalia was right'(!)  Oh really? Uh, isn't that conduct now considered to be a Hate Crime? I was shocked! He sort of ruined an otherwise ecstatic day for me! My boyfriend who was with me as well and he was outraged. So this store must be homophobic like their rude and base lowlife employees!

Two: their sandwich I had ordered at their deli. A turkey sandwich on a Dutch roll. It tasked okay, but later at home... uh hem! Well, shall we just say that I got sick. Bad stomach pain and cramping followed by nasty and vicious diarrhoea! Almost went to ER! My friend called the San Francisco Health Department and filed complaint.

Better to go the seven blocks west on Cabrillo to Safeway. They too have a deli. Good and they shan't leave your intestinal tract in tatters!  ...And they are far cheaper -- and nicer! Or there is also on Haight and Stanyan, Whole Foods. They too have a good deli. bit expensive but also will not disembowel you!

Please avoid Argüello Super at all costs! They are very unprofessional, rude, homophobic, overtly expensive, and their food evidently not all that safe!
author: Tatsuhiro S.

description: "Meh. I've experienced better" is about perfect. They're clean and have a lot of variety when you're in a pinch, but their deli is not great. I got a spinach and feta calzone, and it smelled really wet and didn't taste much better. The pasta salads are sad. The deli is especially overpriced. I get it - it's San Francisco, but this place is not quality.
author: Catie R.

description:
Hands down Best turkey sandwich in the city. $6.99. They literally carve from a fresh baked roasted turkey. It's like thanksgiving everyday!  Get this on sourdough, grab a few sides and stroll to the flower conservatory a couple blocks away in GG park for a picnic. Some sides to consider : San Francisco potato salad, slaw, fresh fruit , rice pudding. 

The market itself is nicely merchandised.  Great selection of organic fruit and vegetables. 

Lots of seating outdoors as well.
author: Sam S.

description: Sandwiches are fresh staff is very friendly. However the sandwiches aren't to die for I've had better very clean environment. I'd eat here again if I was close to the store and hungry but otherwise I wouldn't go out of my way for a sandwich from this store. 3.5 stars for me.
author: Pj B.

description:
We just stopped by but it looks like a very popular deli. 

So we got their famous dark meat Turkey sandwitch on Dutch crunch. I really liked the real juicy turkey chunks. 

When you're in the neighborhood stop by.  Highly recommended!
author: Pooky C.

description: Cool local market with a solid selection. The guy bagging the groceries was super friendly - he totally sold me on the chicken chili for next time. When I walked out, there were hippies strumming their guitar on the street, which punctuated the experience.
author: Andrew K.

description: Got a most delicious hot turkey sandwich here. The turkeys are fresh out of the rotisserie and the meat is hand carved to order. You can choose from a variety of breads, I got mine on a fresh croissant. This was the freshest turkey sandwich I've had from a deli. No preservatives, just freshly cooked. I'm sorry I didn't snap a photo before I ate it.
author: Marilee P.

description:
Argh. This is such a difficult review. On one hand they probably have the best turkey sandwich. On the other hand turkey sandwiches aren't that exciting and they really can't compete with other sandwiches. 5 stars if you really like Turkey sandwiches. Otherwise 3 stars in general for a perfectly good but not exciting sandwich. 

If you decide you want to get a turkey sandwich do as Thi N recommends (http://www.yelp.com/biz/arguello-super-market-san-francisco#hrid:T8W3-4CFlTsLRAjuEtj2Bw) - dutch crunch, dark meat, no pickle, cranberry, swiss/provolone cheese ($9.22 including tax). It IS a good turkey sandwich but it's not in my top 10 favorite sandwiches.
author: Jean K.

description:
I came here with my family for the deli sandwiches for the first time.

My mom got the "famous" turkey sandwich, which she did not like at all. She said it was very, very dry.  What's super lame is for one slice of bread, they used the heel (end piece of loaf) of the bread for her sandwich!  I've never, ever seen a deli do that.  Also, she said there was almost no mayo, which is unusual because usually deli sandwiches have too much mayo.

The other weird thing is they don't serve water.  You have to buy bottled water. Ok.  My sister bought a big jug of water and then we asked for cups.  The guy at the counter said they could not give us cups.  I thought that was weird, so I asked the girl at the register.  She said that if we paid 25 cents each, we could have cups. Ok, fine.  We just spent $50 for 5 sandwiches and we have to pay another $1.25 for paper cups? Lame.  And if you must charge, shouldn't cups be like 10 cents?

I've been in for the market many times, usually as an "emergency" because everything is pretty pricey.  Won't be back for the deli!
author: Miss W.

description:
Arguello Super Market makes their turkey sandwiches with turkey meat sliced directly off a fresh roasted turkey.  I seriously love watching the guys here go to the oven and slice the meat for my sandwich right in front of my eyes.  You can choose from white or dark meat or both.  I always order thusly: the turkey sandwich, dark meat, on dutch crunch, no pickles, with swiss/provolone and cranberry sauce.  I took the Mr. here for the first time and he decided to venture off with his own order and he ended up coveting my sandwich.  Just saying.

I tried their chicken salad sandwich once, only because they ran out of turkey, and it was also quite delicious, though it was hard to contain the chicken salad in between the bread.

Besides the sandwiches, Arguello Super Market is a pretty nice, clean, well-stocked market.  They have fresh produce and plenty of goodies among the aisle to accompany your sandwich.  One of my favorite things to do is to pick up a sandwich from here plus a drink and some chips and walk to the park for a picnic.
author: Thi D.

description:
REALLLY GOOD TURKEY..

My friend always gets these at work and she shares with me !! Haha I'm so lucky! I definitely have to make my way out there to get one myself one of these days.

The turkey sandwich on dutch crunch is on point! It is really good and the meat is juicy and not dry like how turkey is usually. It is fairly plain but its delicious. Sometimes plain is good!
author: Tiff C.

description: I have been shopping at Arguello Market since I moved into the neighborhood about 3 years ago. I finally had enough of the rude service from Roy (wears white chefs coat) today and decided to leave this review. First off, I have an emotional support animal that I normally tie up in front. On a night that was poring down rain I was going to bring her in with me and he demanded to see my paperwork. Today he rudely told me that they were out of turkey and chicken when I was trying to get a sandwich. He asked if I could read and grab the sign and shoved it in my face. I will never spend my money in there again because of him. If I owned that market I would get rid of him before he offends more customer. If your reading this Roy you need to learn how to respect people.
author: Brandon B.

description: Some of the worst sandwich makers I've ever encountered. I'm 0 for 5 here.  They never get my order right.  Especially if you don't order the turkey sandwich. They look at you in disbelief. " you not want the turkey sandwich??" Oh and look out for the pirate that works there. Real nice guy...
author: Joe M.

description: I waited about 10 minutes for their famous turkey sandwich. It was good but not great.  The turkey was dry and the bread fell apart. There's definitely better out there.
author: Angelica C.

description: Turkey sandwich was very average. It was nice to have fresh carved turkey in the sandwich but the turkey was dry and didn't have much flavor to it. The sandwich itself wasn't anything special, and definitely not worth the hype that it has.
author: Derrick W.

description:
The sandwiches are solid. I'm sure you'll try their signature roast turkey sandwich but I actually like getting vegetarian sandwiches from here. Can't explain it (I'm not a vegetarian) but I guess it's the quality of the ingredients. Hold the onions unless you are eating alone...

And the grocery store is clean and high end for a local shop.
author: Yohdaddy M.

description:
They make a good deli sandwich. Would have been 5 stars, but the bread is just good, not great.

Note: Had calzones ( chicken and combination) for dinner tonight as I had a late meeting. NOT recommended....basically on par with hot pockets, but more expensive.
author: El B.

description:
We've lived in the Richmond District for a few years now and this market/deli has been on my radar, unfulfilled. We stopped by on a sunny Saturday afternoon to try the famous turkey sandwiches. 

The deli is conveniently located to your left as you enter the market. We came around 3 pm, so we didn't see much of a lunch rush. There were only two guys working the deli counter though, so keep that in mind if you come during a normal lunch hour. The turkeys used for the famous sandwiches are proudly roasting in a large oven, spinning and turning as the deli clerks expertly craft your sandwich. 

I ordered the turkey sandwich on sliced wheat with avocado (no cheese no onion). I like how they use white and dark meat, which gives it more flavor and moisture. My boyfriend had his turkey sandwich on sourdough roll with cheddar cheese and liked his too. He isn't a fan of sandwich rolls and wished the sourdough came in slices like my sandwich did! Overall very delicious sandwiches!
author: Liz G.

description:
This grocery store http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/arguello-super-market-san-francisco?select=N2zFeooCxJZHv34I0BB7fQ#N2zFeooCxJZHv34I0BB7fQ is a popular spot for USF staff & students, who come to buy sandwiches, salads and soups from the deli section. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/arguello-super-market-san-francisco?select=ntYKueJogaPdJxO2P63JCw#ntYKueJogaPdJxO2P63JCw

It's a mini super market with all the basic products (produce, frozen food, etc.) but since I've never bought any groceries here, I have no idea if the prices are comparable to other markets. For years now, I've only purchased sandwiches and drinks. Note that the cashier guy can be a little testy.

And yes, their famous turkey sandwich http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/arguello-super-market-san-francisco?select=Gdv1cQGImxkjs3j_UBhX5A#Gdv1cQGImxkjs3j_UBhX5A is probably the best in SF. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/arguello-super-market-san-francisco?select=dNjCJAYu-VlRWD2wbuQVEw#Bz_xiaSvLR0X2kywA_GSrg Well, at least the ones I got were always excellent. Can't beat the $5.99 price.

Finding parking is almost impossible around this place, so I suggest parking elsewhere and walking here. It's located next door to that sushi nazi place Okina Sushi.

I have no idea what happened to the pics I uploaded many years ago. Seems like Yelp purged all the pics uploaded by previous reviews of this place.
author: Luis C.

description:
I stopped by randomly at this market for a quick bite while on my way to Inspiration Point.
Through the help of yelp, I ordered the HOT TURKEY w/ CRANBERRY and AVOCADO on DUTCH CRUNCH.
One word -- AMAZING.

Turkey sandwiches are usually dry but adding the cranberry and avocado definitely makes it so much more succulent and flavorful.  I ordered half white/dark but I think next time I will order all dark meat to make it even more juicy and tender.

The meat is carved directly off the roasted Turkey.  Comes with the usual stuff - tomatoes, onion, lettuce, etc.  That cranberry doe!

The market itself looked very organized and clean. It was bustling with people at the time but the personnel there seemed very friendly and helpful.  Overall it was a very satisfying experience.  I was in and out.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
This place is a great little mart with fantastic turkey sandwiches. (Go for the hot turkey with cranberry and avocado -- you heard me.)

One star off however because it's a luck of the draw if you get a good sandwich maker (which as we all know can make or break the sandwich.) Most are very nice, but I have noticed one in particular can be quite rude (and also only puts 1 ring of onion, 1 pickle, 1 small tomato, etc on your sandwich.)
author: Jane F.

description:
http://sfist.com/2014/12/04/the_30_best_sandwiches_in_san_franc.php

Eating all the sandwiches. #3

Sunday, January 4, 2015

Went on a Sunday around 1:30pm. There was a never ending line of people getting sandwiches, but they moved through it quickly. Almost everyone was getting the Turkey Sandwich.

I, too, got the Turkey. However, not being a fan of dutch crunch I got the sourdough roll. It was good, but the bread was fighting the sandwich innards for dominance so there was a lot of chewing involved. The turkey itself was delicious. The warm fresh roasted meat was melt-in-your-mouth. There was both light and dark meat. Yum. 

The people watching was also fun.
author: A. T.

description: Got the "world famous turkey sandwich" with everything on it and found it so dry and tasteless. There was barely any mayonnaise and they forgot mustard. I liked the wheat bread because it was soft and it was nice to have actual cuts from the turkey but I would recommend going to get a sandwich next door instead at the Velo Rouge Cafe instead. Otherwise, don't waste your time.
author: Stanley B.

description: Day after Christmas,  Had a hankering for turkey sandwich. This is the place. Real turkey.  All good today. Finished with a chocolate chip cookie.  Now ready for a nap.
author: c g.

description:
We were walking to the conservatory of flowers on a Sunday, and I wanted a soda, so we popped in here.  There was a huge line at the deli counter - like 15 people deep!  I asked the cashier and she said it is for the turkey sandwiches (and it is actually printed on their bags - something like "home of the world famous turkey sandwich")

I was obsessing about this turkey sandwich potential while visiting the conservatory, so we decided to get a couple on the way back home for our "lupper".  We decided to eat half on the tables outside, once we opened them up, they were really nothing special, and there wasn't much turkey in either one of them.

Now looking at the Yelp reviews ...If ONLY my turkey sando looked like the photos on Yelp.  My sandwich was woefully lacking in turkey, 2 measly med-thin slices on a large sourdough roll.  More bread than anything. In order to even taste the turkey I had to break a piece out of my sandwich. it was pretty good, but how could I tell with so little of it. 

The 2nd half of my sandwich I ate open-faced...even then I would say the turkey was lacking but certainly better than the first half.  Sadly I won't be back, such potential lost. Sadness abounds.
author: Amy W.

description:
This review is specifically for the Hot Turkey sando on Dutch Crunch.

Apparently this place is also a grocery store? Didn't notice. I was face deep in turkey-avo-cranberry.
author: Ross H.

description:
Arguello's turkey sandwich!!

Best turkey carved right off a roasted turkey and sandwiches made to order. Lettuce, tomatoes, mayo, dijon mustard, and red onion. All the basics, nothing overdone. You can ask for light meat, dark meat, or both, based on your preference.

Try it on a sourdough roll (chewy exterior) or Dutch Crunch (soft and buttery)!

Can't speak for the rest of the super market, but the deli is worth the trip. There's a line, but it moves quickly!
author: Jennie W.

description:
Best turkey sammy i've ever had. Straight up. It was warm and chunky - not like sliced deli meat, but actual turkey meat. I got sourdough bread, but it was too thick so I just picked it apart NBD. the pickles on the sandwich tickled my tongue, they were so good. The market has amazing hummus, chips, and great selection of drinks to go with your sandwich.

It is a convenience market, so prepare to pay extra for items.
author: Kailey O.

description:
I come here basically every day that I have class at USF for a turkey sandwich on Dutch crunch. Their sandwiches are arguably some of the best in the city.  

In addition to great sandwiches they have a large variety of foods for sale. Samosas, pasta salads, tuna salad, dolmas, calzones to name a few. 

Seeing as it is a supermarket they have fresh produce as well as all of the staples any household could need. 

It's a great little neighborhood store with friendly staff.
author: Chris S.

description: Love this place! Fresh produce! Got the turkey sandwich it was so good. Coffee is pretty good too. Always pop in when in that part of the city!!
author: Sinead M.

description:
Please note that this review is geared toward the deli, specifically this world famous turkey sandwich.

Now, I must inform the reader that I, a friend of mine, and whichever mutual friends available have formed "Club de Sandwich" (get it? Like Club Sandwich but classier?? Fiiiiiine, its lame. But it fits us so well). Club de Sandwich is on a mission to seek all sandwiches in SF (and some in South SF), and find the yummiest sandwich. I'll tell you right now - to date, anyone who's advertised their sandwich as "the best" or "famous" has disappointed me. Arguello disappointed me less than the others, but it does not deserve a "world" famous title. 

I got the turkey on dutch crunch. No extras (avocado and/or cheese), but with everything on it. Now, I must say it took me a while to eat it - I purchased it in the early afternoon intending to save it for dinner. I know, hot sandwiches would be best, but the taste should still hold up, ehh?

The sandwich...was decent. Just ok. The turkey was surprisingly moist, which is a plus. They give a thick slice of white and dark meat in the sandwich, which helps with the texture. The rest of "everything' on it consisted of some lettuce, tomato, onions, and some sort of sauce. 

Remember kids, a sandwich should hold everything inside...which this one did for the most part. Except...my lettuce was prepared half-out of my sandwich. Like...literally. Imagine one piece of lettuce. Now...imagine half of it inside the sandwich, and the other half outside. I was confused...and opened my sandwich to cram it back inside. STAY IN DAG NABBIT!! Fail, sandwich maker. Please keep all ingredients fully in. You are allowed about half an inch to play around outside the bread, but this was too much.

World Famous Turkey Sandwich, I release thee of thine title!! The only claim you MAY have to this is that USF has a ton of kids from all over the world, and being so close by, I'm sure many of the students have partaken in it.

This being said, the market itself looked like a good place to get a wide variety of food. While waiting for my sandwich, I saw piroshki's, grape-leaf wrapped goodies, and a myriad of foods.
author: Lily W.

description:
Review is solely for their sandwiches

Good sandwiches however DO NOT pay for adding avocado (they give you a couple slivers maybe 1/10 of a whole avocado and charge you about $1.25 for it)

Order avocado 2 times thinking maybe the first was just a fluke, but no, the 2nd time I got less avocado (didnt think that was possible)
author: Daniel A.

description: Super disappointed with their turkey sandwich today. Mind you, I've ordered from them many times and take visitors to try this worlds best sandwich. However, today it's either the new guy or they are skimping on ingredients. The turkey sandwich with white and dark meat and everything on it was more like a veggie sandwich. I asked for avocado and barely got a teaspoon worth. Yes, I'll give them another try but do note that your loyal customers do pay attention at your $9 sandwich.
author: KL H.

description:
I'm writing this review relative to their deli.  The sandwiches are mediocre and the service is often slow.  More importantly they often run out of most breads and certain meats by 6pm.

Normally I'd go elsewhere but they are unfortunately one of the only sandwich shops in the area so choices are limited.

Ultimately it would be great to see the owner act a bit more personable and do better inventory planning.
author: David P.

description: So much for world famous turkey sandwiches. NO WAY!!! Worse sandwiches ever. The turkey sandwich is like eating hard rubber bands and plastic straws. If you like dark meat tendons and dark meat leg ligaments that's what you'll get.  Yuck...this place is terrible and I would not recommend even if it's free.
author: Frankie F.

description: Sadly I must take away a star because of the consistently RUDE dude that works there.  When you call in to order a sandwich he sounds pist off that he has to take your order.  I guess it cuts into his time flirting with all the cute college chicks who work there.  The owner is awesome, but this dude makes me not want to go there.
author: Chelsey G.

description:
Stepped in here to grab a sandwich and some water before heading to the park.

The interior was clean well-lit and modern with a health food store vibe. I ordered their "Famous" turkey sandwich.  Giant slabs of carved breast like you only get at Thanksgiving only juicier.  The other ingredients were pretty basic, if not a little boring, but well proportioned and the bread was super fresh.

In front they have a number of tables which catch afternoon sun... a lovely place to hang out and eat a sandwich with your pooch.
author: Summer S.

description:
I take back some of what I said about Arguello Market. Yes, the meat and produce are still ridiculously over priced, but there are some reasonably priced buys.

The biggest draw remains their delicious turkey sandwiches. Arguello elevates a boring concept: the turkey sandwich, with fresh roasted turkey, fresh crispy vegetables, and fresh Dutch crunch. Sometimes nothing satisfies a lunchtime craving like an Arguello fresh turkey sandwich on Dutch crunch with a dousing of Sriracha!
author: Tomas K.

description: Everything is overpriced and most of their employees are jerks.  Helpful note: their deli closes at 7 even though that's not mentioned anywhere. I walked in at 7:15 and stood at the counter for a solid 5 minutes before anyone said anything to me. It's worth the extra 10 minute walk for me just to go to whole foods instead.
author: Nicki L.

description:
In a jam.

Jimmy Fallon makes it work: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vAFQIciWsF4

Arguello Market does not: No jam available for breakfast sandwiches. That's right. One of the greatest morning condiments ever. Missing.

Was time to improvise. Or just accept a plain bagel with cream cheese for the reasonable price of $2 and a quarter. Add a hard boiled egg for a $1 and a quarter more.

Smooth single shot Jeremiah bean Americano for $2 and (you guessed it) a quarter was better. Rich $2 (even!) homemade chocolate chip cookie for later was the best.

Got out of this one. Left three stars behind.
author: Jason B.

description:
I live 2 blocks away.  I don't mind the slightly higher prices because i like to support neighborhood stores.....but this is the last chance i'm giving Arguello due to the nasty service and attitude by the man with the mustache (MWM).  

I show up at 7:50 tonight to grab 2 cokes, an ice cream bar for my wife, and a couple baby food pouches.  It was 7:58 and MWM comes over and tells me that they are closed and i have to stop shopping.  "i said i have 2 minutes right? i am just going to grab a couple pouches and he says NO, we are closed, no more shopping".  But in a very rude way.

I'm all for neighborhood stores but this one feels FAR FROM IT because of MWM.
author: paul k.

description:
Good solid turkey sandwich    They ran out
Of Dutch crunch bread but It was tasty and I would get it again.  
The pasta salad Bianca was swimming in and had soaked up a huge amount of oil.  Not so good on that front   The San Fran potato salad was pretty good. Losing 1 star for pasta and running out of Dutch crunch which is what everyone raves about.
author: Tad H.

description:
Pros:
- turkey sandwich on Dutch crunch bread (recommended by Eater SF)
- chicken sandwich was good, but not as good as turkey
- HUGE sandwiches
- indoor and outdoor seating for the deli
- order your sandwich and pay at the register
- close to Golden Gate Park, so you can get a sandwich for a picnic

Cons:
- it's a bit weird to eat inside a super market, so you won't really want to stay for long
- this is an SF market, so many grocery items are on the pricier side

Bottom line: I would definitely revisit to grab a sandwich on the way to the park. I probably won't eat in the store again, though. As much as I liked the food, I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to go here.
author: Jiann M.

description:
Coffee is fine--no ceramic cups--no nice designs. 
Sandwiches look wonderful.
author: Patricia B.

description: This claims to be the home of the world's greatest turkey sandwich, and let me tell you... they did not disappoint.  If you want that traditional San Francisco experience... Get this on sourdough and you will love it.  I chose to get mine on sweet roll as I like my bread a bit softer but wow... The turkey was so flavorful and the sandwich was delightfully refreshing after a night of hard drinking.
author: Allison A.

description: I came in the morning to get a sandwich to bring to work for lunch so I got a turkey sandwich with everything on it on Dutch crunch. It was so good! And it stayed well as a lunch- didn't get soggy or gross or anything. I came close to opening time and so I didn't have to wait or anything. The service was polite. I'll definitely come back to try to hot turkey with cranberry and avocado! Super filling sandwich for a good price
author: Kim V.

description:
Today marks the last day I will spend my money at Arguello Super Market. This is my neighborhood grocery store, and for years my husband and I have observed how unfriendly the staff seems. Still, we went back. But today, it was their reaction to me when I brought back a product that was obviously stale that led me to write this review. 

I have a little ritual of grabbing a Justin's Peanut Butter Cup and eating one cup as I hike home with my daughter. Whether it's at the nearby Wholefoods or Arguello Super Market, I've had my share of these organic treats. So I feel qualified to say that when I bit into one today and there was no resemblance of peanut butter in the cup, I knew I had a faulty product. 

I walked back to Arguello and asked for a replacement rather than a refund. And, just in case the next one was faulty, I cracked a cup open while standing in the store, and it turns out that this one was "off" too. Not only did it taste chalky, the inside of the cup was dry and white rather than the color of peanut butter. 

When I brought this to the manager's attention, he pointed out the expiration date which is 2/19/14, and then questioned whether I've had them before, etc. The manager was abrasive, and he treated me as if I was a nuisance and insinuated that I had no idea what these peanut butter cups are supposed to taste like. 

This is not how I wish to be treated by a place where I regularly spend money.  I want to support local business, but Arguello Super Market will not receive any more of my family's money. We will go to WholeFoods or Haight Street Market even if it's a little out of the way.
author: Jenn H.

description:
For me, convenience is king, so I thought i'd give Arguello market a shot, since it's right across the street. 

This market is now my go-to. They have everything I need for grocery shopping at a decent price. In addition to this, their deli serves one of the greatest sandwiches i've ever had.

As a side note, i'm big on customer service, I weight it more than quality of food. Everyone in this store is so friendly! I used to think the women behind the check counter were flirting with me... turns out they're just super nice. :-/
author: Ben Z.

description:
I love Arguello. I've been waaaaaaaaaay too many times since I have friends that live about a block away.

 I still remember the first time I had dutch crunch and it was from this place, so its easy to say that was a huge reason I come back! I love their roasted turkey sandwiches. Although, I expected more out of their breakfast sandwiches, they are pretty bland.

The market is super clean and well kept, but just a tad overpriced. I love coming here for a quick coffee in the morning. The staff for the most part is super friendly, and you can tell they work hard-especially during the lunch rush.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Dude. Ike's sucks. Ok ok ok. It does not suck. But when you go head to head with arguello's Turky sando?  Ike's and there 6k reviews can bite it. Tater tots in a sandwich is just lame for us diabetics. Starch on starch!?  What are you, and Indian deli?

Ok, back to the lecture at hand. Been going to Arguello (the l is silent for you gringos out there) since I got my higher education with the Jesuits around the corner.  Truthfully, they taught me how to buy weed on the Haight.  LSD and shrooms were my minor.

The call. It has been and will always be, the Roast Turkey sandwich on Dutch Crunch. Dutch crunch in every other iteration is wack. Might as well dry out a burger bun and sprinkle corn flakes on top. Hey, that's a good idea. Maybe I'll stuff it with jalapeño poppers. And onion rings. And zucchini fries. Arrrrgh!!!

Sorry bout that. 

Order your sandwich with no cranberries please. Mos def take the white jack cheese, salt and pepper, mayo, lettuce, tomatoes, onion.  The key here, ask for some skin and make it 50/50 white and dark meat. Also, if you have to get it during there rush hour, order it Togo. Just get more then one out respect brah!

Get it Togo. Make a left out the exit and walk into golden gate park.  That's a whole nother slice of goodness to your plate. Thank me later.
author: Chris K.

description:
Someone asked me if the turkey sandwich from Arguello Super Market is any good and this was my answer, "Only the BEST turkey sandwich I've ever had!".

True story and I've seriously had about a billion turkey sandwiches in my 24 years. 

How do you beat turkey carved from the bone to order? Or freshly baked dutch crunch bread? Slap on some cranberry and you've got Thanksgiving every day!

Now we all know that people in San Francisco do not like to walk even a block, I'm happy to say I'm willing to walk 10 blocks from my work to pick up this sandwich. 

Yum! Best turkey sandwich ever!
author: Tiffany U.

description: Such a cute neighborhood market!  I wish we had one similar in Long Beach, instead of the liquor stores and MJ dispensaries.  The turkey sandwich was delicious and deserves fame.  Rotisseried, juicy turkey.  Fresh bread, lots of different cold deli salads.  Great little place.
author: Fernando A.

description:
Was visiting a friend in DC and decided to have lunch here because it was impossible to get to where we wanted to go due to the Bay to Breakers race. 

Excellent selection of sandwiches and drinks. Well it's a full on grocery store, so that's to be expected. I certainly enjoyed mine.
author: Dennis O.

description:
They have hired several new girls to work the register and they are very sweet.
The man who owns the place has good intent.
author: Dianne N.

description: Today was a disappointment!  My turkey sandwich was not made to my instructions.  ALSO, something I never noticed before:  While I was waiting for the sandwich, there was a thick layer of dust under and around their weight scales.  UGH!  Please clean the granite top of the deli display.
author: Diana S.

description:
I really love this place and it's deli. They have great sandwiches: their famous hot turkey is great as is all the other sandwiches on rolls. 

They also have really neat grocery items unique drinks. For me this place rocks.
author: David G.

description:
I used to live around the corner from this market and the deli used to a treat for impromptu picnics in the park (and many lazy dinners :)) reasonably priced, get their salami on Dutch crunch role. (Fun fact, they don't have this in the Netherlands - much to my disaapointment, the closest is tiger brood but doesn't come close) 

The prices are actually pretty good for the brands they offer.

I was able to stop by on my recent trip to sf and the salami Sammie was just as tasty as I remembered.
author: Sue K.

description:
Turkey sandwiches are not exactly the stuff fantasies are made of, now are they? But a friend of mine said he'd read the turkey sandwich here was so good that one food writer claimed he could happily eat one every day for a year.

On this advice, we picked one up (along with a salami sandwich) to take to the beach. And while good, possibly even better than any other turkey sandwich before it, it's still not something I'm in any rush to eat again.

And I certainly wouldn't want to eat it every single day for a week, much less a year.

It should be noted, however, that we did not have cranberry or mayonnaise on our turkey sandwich. Perhaps these are crucial components to bliss and by missing them out we were denied deliciousness? It's possible...

Or maybe turkey's truly as uninspiring as I always imagine it to be.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Update from 2010-06-06.
Three years later. (2013-03-29) I wish I could give this place a zero star!  Still NO apology, and as I live near this market, I still see this one employee who had exhibited his homophobic tendencies when I used to shop there, still at the check-out counter (normally unless they are real busy, they only have one check-out clerk).  He is the ^front line' and so-called 'ambassador' for the business.  He is the one who the general public comes into contact with.

From my past experiences several years ago, this place seemed to be rather homophobic in nature.  Shame for being in San Francisco that prides itsself on tolerance (anyway at least it used to be so).

I am still boycotting this place as I have Safeway, Smart & Final, and even Whole Foods as an alternative to me in close proximity to me. No point in shopping at a homophobic business.

Plus even with their competion nearby (Safeway which is open generally 24/7) this place still has never expended its hours and still closes at eight at night!

Lasrly, just before I stopped shopping there, I had discovered that their quality in their sandwiches had been on the wane.  Plus the fact that once I had ordered something by phone, and they made the wrong order.  Instead of apologising for their mistake, when I came in to pick up my order and discovering it was not correct, they made a scene and embarrassed me in front of the public!  VERY unprofessional!

I would not recommend this place at all!  The food being not as good as once was, and very bad and unprofessional conduct by some of their employess -- and seems to be outright homophobic as well.
author: Akinato K.

description:
I didn't really intend to get a sandwich but hot darn if the sight of those huge succulent turkeys spinning on the rotisserie didn't make my mouth water. I got a roasted turkey sandwich (I stretched it into two meals) and a few reasonably priced grocery items. Having all of that under one roof saved me from making an extra stop.

Great spot to pick up picnic items for the park.
author: Loli L.

description:
I live in the East Bay, so I will not be returning to Arguello Super Market, but seeing as how there was nothing else to shop around in this area, we checked out the super market.

They had a very nice selection of grapes and interesting baked goods, candy, and ice cream.

For a small little store, they had a very nice selection! It was worthwhile for us to buy our groceries here and drive it back across the bay! I liked how they have a small area inside where you can eat. For a small store, there was a good, healthy flow of customers.

Maybe this is how all SF neighborhood markets are...I wish I had a non-chain grocery in my area!
author: Poiuytrewq A.

description:
5 Stars for the Turkey Sandwich guys and the sandwich.

This Review is about their business practice. In addition to the turkey sandwich I ordered today, I bought a small container of guacamole to add into my sandwich. As I was paying for my purchase, the manager/owner (tall, balding guy with glasses and white dress shirt) took my guacamole and walked back to the aisle I had found it at. Confused, I asked the cashier what was going on. He simply told me, "we're getting you a better one, go have a seat and I'll bring it over to you". A few moments passed and the manager returned with "the better one". 

The "better one" was definitely better for their wallet. I had been given one that was due to expire earlier than the original one I had picked out. In addition, the container was wet and had a brownish liquid around it. When I opened the container, the guacamole was already browning and tasted kinda funny. As I write this, my stomach is beginning to churn... darn you guacamole!

I wanted to approach the manager and ask  him why I was given such a poor product when the one I originally picked was perfectly fine, but he avoided me and went as far as to greeting another customer and starting up a conversation with him. 

Not wanting to be rude, I  didn't interrupt and decided to leave it at that. I'm thinking about contacting the city to file a complaint because this is just ridiculous.
author: One L.

description:
Disclaimer:  This review is for the deli ONLY.  I realized that Arguello Super Market's products are all terribly overpriced, so do not come here to do your grocery shopping.

With that said, the World Famous Roast Turkey sandwich is delicious.  It's not a garden-variety turkey sandwich because they roast the turkey every morning!  Get it with Dutch Crunch and pepper jack and you will be just in love.  Try to go early because they run out of turkey fast.
author: Christine A.

description: I've been meaning to try the turkey sandwich for years and finally got around to it before heading to Hardly Strictly Bluegrass. The sandwich was a bit too bulky on dutch crunch - it was hard to get a bite with everything on it, and I actually preferred taking the turkey out and eating most of it separately.  I'll admit that I forgot to ask for cranberry sauce and was bereft of it. I'd definitely have it again if I were in the area and hungry, but wouldn't go out of my way for it. The beer selection was ok.
author: Lisa K.

description:
The sandwiches are not my all time favorite, but they did the trick. The Dutch crunch bread was super yum, but the turkey part was ehh. It wasn't served hot or pressed like I had hoped, but ohh well you win some and lose some.... Either way I was headed to the beach so who cares, right? 
The market itself was cute and had a good selection of the necessities. Probably wouldn't go back for a sandwich because there are too many other good options, but hell, if you are hungry and close by it's really not that bad.
author: Ladybird G.

description: Great place to stop for groceries, food, and conveniently located!
author: Thomas H S.

description:
4.5 stars...no lie for a solid fresh-roasted turkey sandwich

I love delis who use non-processed, and non-brined meats.
Case in point, I give you Arguello Super Market.

Walk in and order-up your selection at the deli-counter to the left.
Marvel at the large selection you can choose from the chalkboard-sign above.
Gaze at all the other deli sides from their display cases.

Their sandwich-technicians will custom make your sandwich any way you want.
(I guess within reason...)

I like mine with provolone cheese, everything (except the mayo), 
and their dutch-crunch bread.  You can request white or dark meat. 
I usually tell them a combination of both.

They have a rotisserie-unit with two birds roasting.
One bite and you'll know this is similar to what you would make at home.
Sensible price for this kind of sandwich (under $9 with a diet Coke).
I sometimes grab two of them...

So get the fresh-roasted turkey sandwich at Arguello's already...
Your hunger will disappear in no-time!!!
author: Derek N.

description: I'm new the neighborhood and was so stoked yesterday when I went to the Arguello Market for the first time.  High quality produce and dairy, top shelf meats, and many healthy choices in all categories.  Definitely a great choice for a small run of groceries.
author: Michael D.

description:
This review is specifically for the roast(ed) turkey sandwich.

I don't go traditional (no mayo, pickles, all that crap) - I just get dutch crunch with the turkey (both dark and white meat), lettuce, tomato, and cucumber. It tastes the way driving to the beach with the top down feels. I will say that.

Also, it's just over six bucks for a whole lot of sandwich. Amazing.
author: Jiordan C.

description: I just moved to this neighbor 4 months ago. It was lucky for me that I have this great super market just 1 block away. This super maker has good karma, it has good natural sun shine inside, friendly employees, clean and various of foods considering its not that big size. And it has its own sandwich corner. My favorite is hot pastrami with soft role. It tastes very good. I feel joy whenever I shop here. I can't comment about prices since I am amateur about it.
author: Andrew S.

description: I love Arguello Super Market. I come here every time I'm too lazy to go to Safeway (and that's a lot). They have everything you could possibly need, at slightly higher prices than you might pay at a chain super market. If you come here, you should try one of their sandwiches from the deli, either turkey or chicken. They are SO good. They also make a mean soy latte!
author: Emma W.

description:
Love having a local market that isn't part of a chain and the stock seems so well tailored to neighborhood choices.

Great deli too but it is always easy to pick up something to cook up for dinner.
author: Jennie M.

description:
I have consistently had very poor experiences with the customer service here. The sandwiches are tasty, but the demeanor of the people making the sandwiches has always been annoyed, unfriendly and flat out rude. No sense of customer service whatsoever, it's almost as if they are annoyed with you for ordering anything. I am having trouble convincing myself to give them my business any longer. 

Cafe on the corner is a stark contrast to prove my point, they understand being polite and courteous makes customers want to return to keep them in business...
author: Emerson 3.

description: I'm not a fan of the turkey sandwich. I had high hopes. I even added avocado and cranberry :( making it $8.50!
author: Ali B.

description: I go to this market pretty frequently lately since it is near where I am staying. It's really pricey, but the quality is decent. I did purchase some "sushi" there the other day. It was uneatable. I immediately returned it. The manager gave me a bit of a hard time about it saying it had just been delivered that day. I said that I believed him, but that it was still uneatable. He gave me a refund. Most of the staff is pretty nice and the famous turkey sandwiches are good, but I'm not sure they are worth $8.
author: Midori H.

description:
I really want to like this place. It's in my neighborhood.. and though it is expensive, they have tasty treats and a great selection of snacks, chocolate, chips, drinks, etc.  The line for the deli on the weekends is often long, and they could improve in terms of stinginess with napkins (they don't give them to you unless you go through the checkout line, and if you buy something pre-prepared from the case, they won't give you napkins.)

But here is the real problem:  one of the owners is distinctly unfriendly, and glares at me whenever I come in (which is now at least 10 times.) I've tried smiling, I've tried saying "thank you" when he rings me up at the register... but I get a grudging and terse thank you in return. Sometimes he just stands behind the girl who works the register and glares. What is up with the stink-eye, buddy? Am I being mistaken for someone else? Does he dislike my mohawk? He clearly doesn't dislike my CASH, so how bout just being a little less of a sourpuss, and I'd come in more often?
author: Lola B.

description:
This review is primarily on their deli sandwich. 

Dutch crunch.
Turkey
Avocado
Provolone
Lettuce, Tomato, Onion, Pickles, etc....

HEAVEN. Literally, the best sandwich ever.

As for the market, I find some of their basic items a bit over-priced. I'll shop there if I'm desperate since it is just around the corner from my house, but usually it is not my cup of tea. Sometimes I feel like the cashier girl is unfriendly, but whatever--she's probably mad she's working a weekend and I'm enjoying a really good sandwich. ;)
author: Amber D.

description:
Purchased a bottle of Nature juice.  Grabbed a paper cup so that I could drink some like a proper human.  Was told to pay 25 cents to purchase the cup...after just spending $10 on a normally-priced beverage in their store.

Classic California nickel & dime bullshit.  I will never return.
author: Alexander P.

description: The Asian girl at the checkout has the customer service skills of a concentration camp guard. I'd rather go to McDonalds.
author: Brendan m.

description:
I'm a fan of the turkey leg....but not a fan of the sandwich.  Sure the "best turkey sandwich ever" was good, but its not extraordinary besides the juicy cut of fresh rotisserie.  The dutch crunch bread it was served on....could have potentially been better, but I still enjoyed it.  

As for the rotisserie portion.....boy they seriously have the operation down.  Maybe 8 turkeys going at the same time, that's some serious business.  And with each turkey comes 2 turkey legs, and in this case, the worker was great to have given me 2 fresh limbs including the THIGH too!  And each piece costing $10, I'm now a super fan of the turkey leg.  And even if its just rotisserie and not bbq'd, its still super duper juicy and flavorful.
author: Vincent K.

description:
It's been a while since I had her. As usual, she's always ready to please and satisfy your hunger for more.

This time around was even better on a dutch crunch!..
author: Gary E.

description:
2.5 stars.
