My friend wanted Subway.  I'm a snob.  I'm never eating a sandwich from Subway.  Plus, the walk is too far from USF.

So I suggested Arguello Super Market.  My friend agreed.

I got the hot turkey sandwich, light mayo, on dutch crunch.  It MUST have been an off day, because the sandwich was COLD.  The turkey breast was fresh but it didn't make up for the tough/stale bread.. it definitely was not fresh.  Unremarkable.

Next time, I'll listen to my friend and we'll get Subway instead.
author: Vivian H.

description:
After reading the rhapsodic reviews of the life changing experience other folks have had eating the infamous turkey sandwich, I decided to schlep across Golden Gate Park from my Inner Sunset digs to sample the gastronomic wonder.   One word.  M-E-H.   Completely underwhelmed by what amounted to a post-Thanksgiving day cold turkey sandwich lunch.  Finished half of it and ended up tossing the rest the next day.  Definitely "been there, done that" and won't plan on reliving the experience.

For truly remarkable sandwich ecstacy, try Rhea's market on Valencia.
author: Todd K.

description:
The best Turkey sandwich in the hood!!
Recently renovated and now has more upscale items. Oh and did I mention the soup? Love it!
author: Mark F.

description:
I really wanted to like it here. I live around the corner and was really excited when we first moved to the neighborhood that we had a local grocery store & deli. I love mom & pop shops, and supporting small businesses. Unfortunately, the prices at Arguello are unbelievably inflated. Every time I do succumb to its proximal convenience I walk out stunned with how much I end up paying for a couple measly items. The service isn't that friendly, I thought after going there so many times the staff would begin recognizing me as a regular and acknowledging that. Nope, no homey, friendly, familial experience here. Actually, I think the cashiers at Safeway are friendlier on average. And the cherry on top: they often are out, or just do not carry many normal, standard, daily items that one would need. (And just a side note, the deli turkey sandwich is OKAY, but it's seriously overrated) So unless I'm *really* desperate I never go here, I just make the 5 block trek to Safeway.

There was one good experience I had here, that I do want to share, I was in desperate need of a razor, I picked up my usual razor and went to the cashier, the total was 21 dollars (which is insane) but i only had 18 dollars and i had left my wallet at home. I told the owner who was working as cashier, and he let me off with paying 18, but said I owed him $3 next time I came in, which was about a month later, but I reminded him (he had forgotten) and everything was square.
author: Shayan S.

description:
Been shopping here for 3 years.

Live across the street: extermely convenient. I think I went in here TWICE yesterday.

Yes, the turkey sandwiches are amazing. Be prepared to stand in a long line to order your sandwich during the weekend, especially on a sunny day when everyone is headed to the park nearby.

The rest of the food/alcohol is pricey. And the produce can be limited sometimes.

I had a great experience a while back when I was sick: was checking out with advil, 8 bottles of gatorade, and some canned soup when the cashier told me "that's not what you need", left, and preceded to come back with 3 containers of their daily made HOT chicken soup. He charged me for only one. An awesome kindness. I won't forget it.

They had whole roasted turkeys and homemade pies this past Thanksgiving, too. Not sure if that's a new thing but I don't remember that going on the year before.

So ya: pricey but convenient. I love it.
author: Gracie W.

description:
Delicious Turkey Sandwich for $7.24. 

Want to know how delicious it was? It had both Dark and Light Turkey meat and wasn't sliced, but take out like leftovers from Thanksgiving. In a word: Awesome
author: Alex M.

description:
Arrived at the sandwich counter at 7:45. They served the people in front of me but refused to serve me because of the time. The next time I arrived earlier and they said they closed at 7pm because they were slow. They need to stick to their posted hours. 

The food's not bad but it's definitely overpriced. Shop elsewhere for any big purchase.
author: Anonymous C.

description:
I'm one of the people who find the turkey sandwich phenomenon here to be quite perplexing.  It's real turkey, on bread, with lettuce, tomato, mayo, a pickle.  You can also get Dutch Crunch.  You can specify dark or white meat. 

I think the reason people go so crazy about this sandwich is that it is real sliced turkey, not processed deli turkey meat.  

Still, that's all it is.  Don't expect something different than that.  But I still give the place four stars because it's a cute place, and if people love this sandwich, I think that's  great.  I mean, why rain on the parade?  

Personally though, I just find the whole thing quite baffling, that's all.
author: Melinda A.

description: What an awesome local grocery store this place is. The produce is always great, unique selection of everything and some great specialty items. The turkey sandwiches are pretty amazing and worth going out of the way for. Arguably one of the best out there.
author: C F.

description: Good prepared food and sandwiches from the guys behind the bar. They're very friendly. Good selection of food and things sold in the store. However, the cashiers could use some training on how to be a bit friendlier to guests.
author: Grey Z.

description: Maybe it's just me. After reading several friends' reviews about their highly touted hot turkey sandwich, I made a weekday afternoon stop here for lunch. When you enter the store and walk up to the sandwich/deli counter on the left, you immediately see the whole turkeys turning in the rotisserie oven. I ordered their trademark sandwich with pepper jack cheese on a dutch crunch, holding mayo. After the sandwich dude quickly put mine together, I headed to the cashier's line and paid for my meal. Perhaps, it was my "great expectations" again, but it just wasn't "the best ever" sandwich for me. When I bit into the second half of the sandwich, it did taste better, probably because the turkey meat was more tender and the fresh turkey flavor finally came out. Would stop in if in the neighborhood, but not a destination place for me.
author: Mike C.

description:
*Review only for deli*

I happened to stumble upon this lovely grocery store yesterday, looked up some reviews which said the turkey sandwich was to die for! So I got a turkey sandwich with cranberry sauce (+$0.75) and on dutch crunch (+$0.99), came out being $7.54 which is alright if the sandwich is amazing. 

After the first bite, you realize why people rave about it, IT'S AMAZING! The nostalgia hits you like a wall, thanksgiving come in July! The thick cuts of moist delicious turkey with awesome cranberry sauce on a warm toasty dutch crunch roll. They give you a lot of meat but not too much to overwhelm the sandwich. Suffice to say, I loved it! Definitely recommended.
author: Kevin L.

description: Smoked Turkey sandwiches are awesome! Normally get Dutch Crunch, but I had to settle for the Sweet Roll on Sunday.. Still great!
author: David B.

description:
Deli is great. Turkey sandwich is a good turkey sandwich- if you go expecting to be penetrated with myriads of flavor or something new- of course you'll be disappointed. 

I have to agree, living nearby and shopping here weekly, the manager is very off putting. I think I saw him smile once but it was towards the obvious owner of the market. Owner needs to tell him to work on his people skills if he is going to work at an effing supermarket. 

$5 min for paying w cards and they don't take American Express. 

Everything but the deli I feel is overpriced. 

All the girl cashiers are helpful, nice, and friendly. I definitely have a crush on one. 

Closes at 8pm and close to 6pm on Sundays
author: Charles U.

description:
Arguello is in my hood and has anything that I could likely want.  However, on this fine Easter Sunday, after a lovely hike in the park with my favorite four-legged companion, I happily strolled into Arguello for a bit of indulgence on my also-birthday weekend.

What I didn't expect was my purchase to be served with a side of bitch.  I don't know what it is about blondie behind the register, but she needs an attitude adjustment. 

It's a good thing I had the Lord's ascension in mind today, otherwise I may have had to deliver it.
author: Tamar D.

description:
the cute little neighborhood market that could ..........

I live a hop skip and a jump away and before Whole Foods blew into town (it's a love hate love relationship for me) I'd pop in here rather regularly for some last minute dinner items. prices are a bit high, selection is not the best, but it's cute and close and that counts for a lot.

but their turkey? now that's where they shine! I don't know that I've had a real turkey sandwich (meaning not that deli turkey stuff) anywhere but at home the day after Thanksgiving. it's such a treat! I'm with Jen K., the veggies could have been a bit fresher, but the turkey is delicious! and on dutch crunch (really good DC, by the by) forget about it! heaven.
author: Rachel W.

description: I love their turkey sandwiches. the service is great. The only time that i had a problem was during the week of Thanksgiving where they did not have any turkey sandwiches for the entire week! I would have assumed that they did not have any turkeys, but I saw turkeys in their roaster. I guess people can order whole turkeys from here...
author: Rex R.

description: Yeah, the prices are high, but the quality is generally high too. And I kind of like the general disdain that the staff has for customers, it just seems appropriate. Oh and this is the best turkey sandwich in the city (or at least in the top 3). The prosciutto sandwich is pretty generous too.
author: Adam K.

description:
roast turkey sandwich + cheese + avocado is worth the almost $10 for the sandwich.  truly a delightful sandwich, and i don't even like sandwiches.  dutch crunch is great

the market looks overpriced from my window shopping while waiting for my sando.
author: Jeffry C.

description:
Being the college student that I am and weighing in at 245 lbs I need food to function and with USF providing very few choices to eat and overpriced food that is always repetitive, I need a spot to fill that void of keeping me well fed. 

Enter Arguello Super Market tucked away on Arguello street. The best part of this place is there selection of foods. You can choose from different types of potato salads, piroshkis, buy some chips, a premade sandwich, sushi, all kinds of foods.

Of course, the Sandwiches are what makes this place. The Fresh Turkey Sandwich is the number one option one your choice of bread, cheese, condiments etc. Costs about $7 for a nice sized sandwich. The staff is very friendly and complete your order to your liking. 

Parking is nearby with plenty of 2 hour over by Mcallister street on the corner or if your lucky, 15-30 minute parking in front. 

Overall, it is a great place to grab a quick bite if your tired of eating at the USF cafeteria if your a student or if your just in the neighborhood looking for a quick bite.
author: Jesus A.

description:
Great sandwich, nightmare parking. 

After numerous circles around the block (it was a Sunday) I dropped my wife off and she knows what I likes/want/needs. After still looking for parking 25 minutes later we met at a park several blocks away with friends and enjoyed a freshly carved turkey sandwich on whole wheat. Simple. Well done. Also, enjoyed their chopped salad, fruit salad and tabouli.

I will good back again if ever in the neighborhood, but will have to Uber it there.
author: Michael R.

description: Dutch Crunch is my favorite type of bread and with the cut turkey it was wonderful! I've never been a big fan of turkey but their sandwich was tasty! I saved one half for the next day and had it cold-tasted just as good.
author: Jaclyn N.

description:
WHO WANTS A TURKEY SANDWICH!!!!!!!!!!

Their turkey sandwich is sooooooo good. They use actual cuts from turkey, the cuts are thick and big and most importantly, VERY delicious. Since I live 2 blocks away, I would get the cold turkey sandwich and heat it up with my microwave for 30 seconds for the cheese to melt (this was actually my boyfriend's idea). I initially thought the bread will be soggy after you microwaved it, but surprisingly, it's not soggy at all! (I heat it up in its paper package still). The cheese will be nicely melted and the bread will be nice, crunchy, and warm. Sit down for a nice movie and just relax with the warm sandwich in your hands.

SO GOOD. I just got so hungry writing this.. Good thing I live 2 blocks away!!
author: Erica L.

description:
I love their selection, but I'm not a fan of the $5 minimum for debit cards--that's right, debit cards, not just credit cards. Even after debit card reform lowered the cost per transaction, and even though PIN-based transactions are cheaper, this store will not let you pay electronically if your order total is less than $5. Seems a bit draconian to me.

(And they don't take American Express, the one card that would let them avoid a per-transaction fee entirely.)
author: Omar Y.

description:
The sandwiches are pretty good.  In fact, the sandwiches are the only criterion I have for judging this place, as I've never stepped foot inside it.  But I've had the sandwiches for going on five years now, and they're usually great, sometimes spectacular, and every once in a while disappointing.

So why only three stars?  Well, I had potato salad from here recently that really didn't agree with my stomach.  I recently had surgery as well, so I'm sure the potato salad by itself didn't cause the pain, but I know it aggravated it, and I have a feeling either the mayonnaise or some other ingredient was expired or going on expired.  

Thankfully, I still had some prescription painkillers on hand, but if I hadn't?  Well, I might have sued Arguello Super Market for my emergency-room visit.  I'm kidding.  I think.
author: John S.

description:
Okay so I never thought I could get a less than amazing sandwich from this place but today it was meh. 

The veggies were not fresh, seemed like day old or something? The bread was slightly stale too! Maybe they didn't a shipment on sandwich stuff because it was labor day? Who knows.

Also just an FYI about arguello- if you ask for pepperchinis- forget it! Out of the last five times I have asked for them, they've actually made it onto the sandwich maybe once or twice. Grr.
author: Jen K.

description:
Okay, perhaps the moderate-to-high(ish)-priced grocery selection is another story... but the DELI is BOMB (does anyone still say that?). For all the right reasons:

1. Affordable
2. Friendly, efficient service
3. Fast-moving long lines (honest)
4. THE VEGGIE SANDWICH
5. THE VEGGIE SANDWICH

Right, so, as a vegetarian, I have not experienced the orgasm that must be the "famous turkey sandwich," but I can assure you that this veggie delight is so. well. worth. your time & dollas. The veggies are fresh, the bread is YUM, and they do NOT skimp on the avocado. The portion is big enough to last me two meals (although I have been known to devour the whole thing in one sitting, like most other normal eaters), and did I mention that it's just $4.99?! If you're worried about the line during the lunch rush (and understand that there WILL be a line), call in your order ahead of time & waltz by the grumbling unfortunate others.

Also, the guys working the cash register are friendly in that oh-hey-I-see-you-all-the-time-so-we-acknowledge-each-other-civilly kind of way, which is cool and all... but you should ultimately come here for the sandwiches. If that wasn't already clear.
author: Sam S.

description:
So, when I used to live down the street I would shop here all the time, but since I moved, I'm never really in the area.

Luckily for me, after Bay to Breakers it was close to 1pm, I was close to a hangover and starving and I happened to walk by Arguello Supermarket. Decided to get me a sammich. and holy shit,

PROCIUTTO SANDWICH 

Best sandwich in the world. How do I know this? I ate half and saved the other side to eat when I was sober, so I'd know for sure if it was good or not and it wasn't just the excessive alcohol talking.

Try it. And don't forget to add chz and avo!!
author: Marisa R.

description:
For all the talk of San Francisco's culinary sophistication, we sure do have a strong market for good ol' turkey sandwiches.  I've lost count of the number of little delis I've been to that will whip you up a little bundle of Dutch-Crunched joy.

Chalk Arguello Super up on that list too.  For those who think it's the *only* turkey sandwich in town, make sure you try New Crockery first.  But yeah, Arguello's is damn good, not messy at all, and it comes on some of the most perfectly done Dutch Crunch ever.  Don't forget to order it with the cranberry sauce, because they may not ask you.  Big props that you can actually come in here at 9 AM to get your sandwich, although even then there was a wait.

Tough call on whether this is Inner Richmond or Lone Mountain.  I sort of think of Arguello as the boundary, and Arguello Super is on the east side, but...my Neighbo-Sense is telling me to go with Richmond.
author: Wes M.

description: Deli counter here is really doing their thing. Of course the classic turkey sandwich is the bread and butter but they've got some other goodies back there too. Check em out and get a sweet roll if your not into Dutch crunch
author: Kevin P.

description: Delicious turkey sandwich, good selection of food and necessities, even have easy burn fire logs! It's a great place to have around the corner
author: Barbara S.

description: If people don't agree that this is the best turkey sandwich ever, they obviously ruin it by not getting cranberry, Dutch crunch, or cheese. If you don't like cranberry at least add avocado. I can't eat a turkey sandwich anywhere else.
author: Jenna R.

description: Okay, I do not like turkey sandwiches.  This was the best turkey sandwich I have ever had! When they say world famous it is not just a kitschy saying, they mean it.  The giant rotisserie had the biggest turkeys I had ever seen.  Will definitely be back.
author: April M.

description: Yet another review about the Turkey Sandwich - amazing! Got it with avocado on sweet roll. The turkey was steaming and so freakin delicious. I am hooked!
author: Maggie F.

description: Best turkey sammies in all of SF! The long line is worth the wait. Be sure to get the 50/50 with cranberry sauce.
author: Mel C.

description:
Overpriced and the service is mediocre at best. Parking is nonexistent, better walk here if you need to come here at all. 

Sunday morning, my 2 year old needed milk. My wife prefers to give her Berkeley farms -- so I couldn't get the milk at the more conveniently located and better operated Safeway a few blocks away. I arrived at 7:30 -- doors shut, clerk behind counter glances over and ignores me. 

They eventually opened, I grab the milk and when I check I mention to the owner that they did not open at 7:30 and tells me -- "yeah its Sunday." Then he smiles and tells me he heard I had stopped by earlier. No apology, just a smile and gives me a what are you gonna do attitude. 

Don't even think of using a credit card unless you spend more than $10 -- by the way stores are not allowed to put these policies in place, it is a violation of their contract with the credit card companies. But stores do it anyway because they know they can get away with it. 

We wonder why Safeway is shutting this place down? Safeway carries almost the same products and has better service. Heck at 7:30 I would've been happy with a place that kept its posted operating hours.
author: Alex P.

description:
This is a review for the actual market and not the deli as I haven't tried anything from there yet.

Everything is pretty much overpriced. I wouldn't go grocery shopping here unless you really needed to for some reason... though Safeway is only 7 blocks away, has a larger selection, and better prices.

I'll have to try the turkey sammich some day, but the market itself is meh.
author: Timothy L.

description: I love the freshness of everything in the store. You know you're getting good quality food. BUT THEY DON'T HAVE LEMON JUICE. Eff that. But they have really good ice cream.
author: Wendy L.

description: From the outside it looks like a friendly place with good food. Inside, not so much. I walk in, with my service dog, and the guy behind the cash register rushes out from behind the register yelling, yes actually yelling, "HEY! HEY! HEY!" and pointing at me and my dog. This person has some serious communication problems. Any normal person would ask calmly "Is this a service animal?" but not this guy. This guy actually rushed me, yelled at me, and got the attention of everyone in the entire store. I was completely mortified. I was so shocked that I was barely able to say "this is a service animal" and push past him, only to find that their food selection was the same as what you'd find at a gas station. Don't waste your time here or set yourself up to be harassed by the employees.
author: Thomas S.

description:
Get the roast turkey sandwich. They roast whole turkeys here so you could get white and dark meat. The price is not too bad ($6.74) and they put enough meat. 

Will definitely come back. I say 4 stars!
author: roderick s.

description: Shitty sandwiches they're not at all what'd you'd expect they have potential but I wouldn't eat here again.
author: Chavin A.

description:
I've been going to Arguello for years. And back in the day, I would have given it a million stars based on the roast turkey sandwich. However, I have recently noticed that every time I go there, a) the turkey is not good - usually overcooked; b) the employees behind the deli counter have a hard time understanding my order and getting it right; and c) they reallllllllly skimp on the toppings - one pickle slice and a thin tomato, if you're lucky.

I work nearby and used to rely on Arguello for a decent lunch. Now, it's sort of becoming a last resort. I will go in for a basic ham and cheese sammy, but not much else. Bring back the quality!
author: Beth T.

description:
All Hail the delicious, ambrosial,fabulous TURKEY Sandwich!
(with a cranberry and avocado, mmmm)  I could probably eat this everyday for a month and never complain.  That month would be called,"Celebration of everything beautiful about humanity month"  This  sandwich makes a compelling argument for world peace.  If everyone in the world could just gather round this delicious concoction .  The other deli items are good as well, but they pale in comparison to what I shall loving refer  to as "Lady Elmira Dankington".  Not only a good deal at the deli, Lady E is also an exceptional quantity of food, plenty to share with a friend.
I love this sandwich.
Also the creole potato salad is really good.
author: Steve F.

description:
I have to say that I agree with all the reviews stating this place makes the BEST TURKEY SANDWICH EVER because it does...literally.
This is a high quality sandwich. They roast their turkeys right at the counter so it's always fresh and oh so moist and tender. 
Oh and two words DUTCH CRUNCH...turkey and dutch crunch just might be the best pairing in town. Fresh vegetables decorate the sandwich and of course I always add avocado. You are definitely paying for quality with this sandwich. 
Bring this bad boy to the park and have a bottle of wine in hand and you will definitely enjoy yourself.
author: Charlotte M.

description:
The deli and prepared foods here are so delicious!  They have that homemade taste but look very fancy.  The market itself is very small so I don't do most of my grocery shopping here.  In fact, I really only come here to buy coffee grounds, high end crackers and prepared foods from the deli.

You must try their sandwiches when you stop in.  They are decently priced and very filling.  There is a reason so many people rated the sandwiches with 5 stars - it's because that is what their sandwiches deserve.
author: Carmel U.

description: Used to bicycle or scooter here for better candy when I was in elementary school; now walk here for a sandwich. Neighborhood store, nice variety.... sandwiches, spanakopita, kombucha, selection of juices and boxed teas, unusual brands for baked goods, tempting selection of preserves and jams, etc. They carry organic milk in glass bottles-- believe they're one of the few places to do this. If you're in the area it's very convenient!
author: Bunny C.

description: I usually get my turkey sandwiches at cal mart I usually get hot turkey breast on sweet French roll with mayo and lettuce only .it is pretty good there. oh when you get a sandwich card you buy 10 get one sandwich free.ok today my husband gets me one from arguello super after hearing rave reviews from a friend. ok he gets me a sourdough bread with mayo more like a salad dressing / sweet sause  and there was a little turkey with some dark meat and white meat in the sandwich .it was $6.99  ..oh today I ate the other half after I scraped the salad dressing off and bit into the sandwich, it was a bone you know the kind that you get from the leg  not good. somebody could choke on that. lucky I saw it and took it out .i definitely would not go back ! i see they use turkey scraping to fill their sandwich.oh a friend got a Cajun turkey from kfc and it was surprisingly good and moist.. might be a holiday thing though.
author: Nellie J.

description:
Yup, bang-for-your-buck deli.

For the price, by far my favorite sandwich in the city.

I used to always get the "Famous Hot Turkey" sando, which is amazing, but have recently branched out to pastrami, salami, deli turkey, and proscuitto.  

Being happy with nearly every sandwich I have eaten from Arguello, and wowed with a delicious proscuitto sandwich for $7, I give this deli my stamp of approval.
author: Phil P.

description: I used to LOVE the Arguello turkey sandwich but the last two visits the sandwiches have been mediocre at best.  The bread and the turkey were both very dry and they forgot to put cranberry sauce on like I had asked.  Such a bummer, especially after waiting in line for so long.
author: Katie G.

description:
Well I just got off the phone with France and Germany, and they said they have no idea what Arguello Super Market's World Famous Turkey Sandwich even is. 

But little old me right here in San Francisco thought it was pretty good. I didn't know you could fancify it with cranberry sauce and avocados and exotic cheeses, but it was still a solid sandwich.
author: Catface G.

description:
You can find your great original world famous turkey sandwich here.  No, the turkeys aren't famouse the sandwich is!  I've heard people knowing about this place who are from out of town... that's how great their turkey sandwich is here.  I don't know too many places that have a fresh roasting turkey on site ready to order.  I've tried their turkey sandwich here twice just to make sure it wasn't a fluke the first time and it was great second time around too.

First time I had it with cranberry, and the second time I had it with avacado.  You can't go wrong either way.  Never too dry and easy to eat.  My favorite turkey sandwich spot I've been able to find.
author: Kevin N.

description: I love my local market. It's not cheap, but it's high quality and the people who own/work here are super nice. They make great sandwiches and sell lots of other high quality foods. The other day some a-holes shoplifted here. You steal from my Arguello family, you steal from me.... watch your backs. They also have a very good flower selection so if your going to give a girl flowers this is a great place to hit up. Beautiful bouquets for $10.
author: Heather J.

description: Not only the best turkey sandwich, but overall a great market.
author: Dilly M.

description: A neighborhood gem! Arguello has at least 1 of everything - whenever I need something in a pinch I'm confident that I can swing by and find it. The staff is friendly, the beer is cold, and the sandwiches are amazing!
author: Matt T.

description: Awesome Turkey sandwiches like everybody else has already said. That being said, all other sandwiches are just mediocre and the market itself is pretty damn expensive. Their turkey sandwich is their saving grace and the only reason this place got 4 stars instead of 2, because it is just THAT good.
author: BP R.

description:
Just learned about this place from a friend a couple of months ago. Ever since, I am loving it!! Fresh Roasted Turkey on Dutch Crunch. I cannot believe I didn't know about this place for all these years!!

The older gentleman who seems to be the owner is very reserved but  really nice.
author: Wakaknee J.

description: They have the best fresh turkey sandwich in San Francisco. The turkey is always good and juicy. The only bad thing about this place is its hard to find parking.
author: Ash R.

description: I have been enjoying the Arguello market turkey sandwich since 1990 on sour roll with everything no tomato this is absolutely the best turkey sandwich in Northern California.
author: Walter W.

description: Arguello Market has the best Turkey sandwich in San Francisco - the praise is deserved. They roast the turkeys at the store meaning you get real fresh, carved turkey meat on fresh bread. Get the sandwich on dutch crunch with everything, pair with a cranberry juice, iced tea and/or chips and you've got one of the most enjoyable meals in the city for about $10.
author: Colin J.

description: What would seem like a standard turkey sandwich is anything but. Real turkey from a real bird? Yes please. A mix of juicy, amazing white and dark meat? Why, thank you! Fresh and fast. The cranberry sauce adds a nice touch. Simple and delicious without trying too hard. The store looks nice too...
author: Meredith W.

description:
The goods here are definitely pricier than those that you will find at Safeway or Lucky, but that's because they are better.  I love that there is a section of Irish food products as well as other ethnic foods and a great selection of Amy's Organic everything.  They also carry organic ice cream and Kerrygold cheeses!  If you're looking for something specific, go to a larger store.  If you're looking for something for dinner tonight, go to Arguello.  You'll find tons of things.

I hear the deli is quite good as well.
author: Aishling R.

description:
So Arguello Supermaket and I have an interesting relationship, some would call it love hate. But they've clearly got me hooked on some otherworldly level as I find myself there more often than my debit card would probably like. So here's the deal ...

As much as I like the store and the service I don't recommend it to any one on a budget. They've got a great array of products some specialty mixed in with your everyday type foods and snacks. But other than the fact that you can probably find a better deal elsewhere, I say go for it! It's a great neighborhood establishment, and like I said there is something about this place that's got me hooked. 

And well I guess I DO know what that thing is ... its the deli! Their sandwiches are definitely worth a visit or two or three. In times as I'm segueing from class to work with barely enough time to grab a bite or looking for a quick and easy lunch for a day in the park, they always treat me right! And any place where your turkey sandwich is actually carved from a turkey roasting behind the counter with people able to request dark or light meat, is where you'll find me and that pretty much sums up the quality of the food you get here (high quality meats and fresh produce!) I usually go for the pastrami or like most I have to recommend the hot roast turkey on dutch crunch (add avocado for a little flare!) ... it will definitely leave an impression.
author: Dominique C.

description: You have to get the hot turkey sandwich on dutch crunch with everything on it! so good!
author: Alicia Q.

description:
pretty great sandwiches, but real talk: Roy - the mustache guy - is actually the most incompetent human being in the history of customer service. like, WOW.

once i called ahead and asked if they were still making sandwiches. roy answers with "every day," which, whatever, that's not true, but okay. he said there was no line, so i decided to come in and just order one in the store. i came in, and they told me they were out of turkey, but to come back in half an hour. that was frustrating, but didn't feel like walking all the way home, so i waited. 45 minutes later, Roy said it'd still be another 20-30 minutes, so i went on a walk for ANOTHER half hour and then came back. they said it still wasn't ready, but if i came back in an hour, it'd definitely be ready.

so i went home and came back an hour later. when i arrived, Roy told me that it was 7:02 and they stop serving sandwiches at 7:00. at this point, it'd been over two hours, i'd been back and forth to Arguello three times, and i was about to go home empty-handed. i was THIS CLOSE to flipping out on him when one of the cashier girls recognized that i'd been in and out of the store just trying to get a fucking sandwich for the entire evening and made sure that it happened for me. she's the best. actually, all the cashiers are the best.

AND THEN TODAY, THIS HAPPENS: i call in a sandwich order. after being put on hold three times, i eventually get put on the phone with Roy, who reads the three-sandwich order back to me. i confirm it, he says it'll be about 30-35 minutes, i say thanks, and i hang up. half an hour later, i come in. there's an enormous line because it's 12:30 on a Saturday, and when i get up to the counter to grab my sandwiches, they have no idea what i'm talking about and point me to Roy. Roy acts weird and sheepish and eventually fesses up that he "read the order back to [me] and said 35 minutes and [i] didn't say yes or no" so he cancelled it. 

despite the fact that i totally said "okay, thank you" at the end: why? why would a human being call a sandwich shop, give three hyperspecific sandwich orders after being on hold twice over the course of 10 minutes, get to the final step, and then just mysteriously hang up and not want the order? are you fucking retarded, roy? are you? it's okay if you are.

i fucking cannot with this guy anymore. their sandwiches are SO GOOD and their cashiers are all totally sweet and adorable and Sal seems maybe like an okay guy but HOLY FUCK is Roy just supernaturally awful at his only job. god damn.
author: Uhh B.

description:
Instead of eating expensive nasty museum food, stop by Arguello Super Market, and grab a little nibble. I bought some bananas, pita chips, tabbouleh, and Baked Snap Peas, after a tiresome day at the Academy of Science. 

I wasn't able to try the "World Famous Turkey", but it looked and smelled delicious. The rotisierre chicken spinning in the roaster showcased juicy meat, dripping fat, and crispy skin. Everything at the deli counter looked really fresh. I spotted a couple of mean-looking sandwiches being eaten on the outside tables. 

On our next visit to GG park, this will be a definite pit stop.
author: Robin K.

description: Some of the best roast turkey sandwiches you can get!  Try it with avocado or cranberry on dutch crunch.  But, get there before too late in the afternoon and they run out!
author: Brian L.

description: The turkey is sandwich is as good as everyone says and I love how you can have some cranberry sauce added on there to really get your mouth watering. The turkey in it is juicy and the veggies are fresh. The mustard or whatever sauce is in there is dope and although it makes the sandwich messy to eat it gives the sandwich tons of flavor and a creaminess you can't get tired of. The prices of items in the market are on the premium side but everything is suuper high quality. Love it.
author: Jess E.

description: I like sandwiches. So I came here. Turns out, they really are amazing.  My wife, she didn't like sandwiches until she had one of these. Now we like sandwiches together. Thanks, turkey sandwiches.
author: Zachary L.

description:
Their turkey sandwiches sure are world famous - because I've met people who live outside SF and know about this place. Their turkeys and chickens are roasting alllll day long, so it's pretty fresh roasted meat. 

I always order the Roast Turkey sammie and never really cared much to try other items. In fact, you don't need to try other items. It's really all about the turkey sandwich. I always add cranberry sauce to the sandwich and use dark meat - it gives it a holiday touch that I crave all year for, haha. Plus, turkey sandwiches make perfect picnic items in Golden Gate Park on Sundays! :) 

I live really close to Arguello Super Market, so it's also super convenient for me to buy random food and household items if I'm too lazy to walk to Safeway or Clement. It's not super cheap, but it saves me time if I'm running out of time. 

....and I have heard comments about seeing handsome young men in the market on Sundays. Maybe I don't go enough to see these handsome young men, haha. ;)
author: Kanara T.

description:
I live right across the street, from their door to mine is about 40 yards, so I will give it props for being insanely convenient. But with the convenience comes the inevitable price: its price. I think the best metaphor for the whole pricing scheme of the Market can be summed up in a $3.49 charge for a plastic child's toy yo yo. Holy bejesus. 

Despite the price, the sandwiches are very reasonable and the hot turkey is of course epic. I usually utilize the market for the bare minimums: bread, cheese, 6-pack  (yes alcohol is in that group) and do the rest of my shopping at safeway.

still its a great location

EDIT: upon perusing the other reviews I think I need to step in here and defend the cashier with the mustache. The dude is gruff, but he does his job well and he's certainly never been rude to me. Lighten up people
author: Jay C.

description: Love their deli counter & the sushi.  All of it is great.  Fresh produce, a bit limited but still good.  Nice to have a clean, well maintained market in the area.
author: Donna W.

description:
Hands down the BEST fresh turkey sandwich!!!  I figured I wanted to see for myself what all the hype was about this mom & pop deli sandwich.  When I walked in and saw 4 turkeys roasting I KNEW it was gonna be tantalizing my taste buds from the first bite.  Oh boy was I right, the dutch crunch roll was AMAZING & so was the flavorful juicy turkey that was packed inside.  They also do not skimp on the meat inside the sandwich like your other typical sandwich makers.  You certainly get your bang for your buck with this turkey sandwich!  It's worth much more than the $5.99 that's for sure!

I'm salivating right now as I write this review.  I know what I will be having for lunch again today :)
author: Jennie W.

description: Amazing Turkey sandwiches. Fresh smiles and Delicious products. Would recommend to anyone.
author: Matt H.

description: Let me start by saying that I really like this market and normally have had great service. Unfortunately I recently had an experience very much like Jenn D (review below). I purchased a pint of milk and when I got it home and opened it, it was spoiled. I returned it to the store within an hour, with the original receipt, to exchange it for a new carton. The cashier was extremely rude and behaved as if and insinuated that I was lying. The experience was incredibly insulting. I like supporting local business but it's not worth being treated like a thief. Hopefully the management can reverse this trend.
author: Briana M.

description: Great local market. delicious deli sandwiches, lot's of local brands, convenient to get all the fixin's for a picnic in the park, plus really great staff!
author: carolyn a.

description:
My favorite sandwich spot in the city.

Fresh Mozzarella on Dutch crunch, with Basil, Balsamic vinegar and mayo. Add red potato salad, Thomas Kemper Ginger ale + USC Football game to that and you have a perfect Saturday!

The sandwich deserves the 5 stars, even though the people that work here aren't the friendliest.
author: Tushar V.

description:
There is no better place to get a turkey sandwich in all of the world.

1.  They carve the turkey to order
2.  Go eat in the park

Done
author: The R.

description:
Mmmm, Arguello's sandwiches.

They're delicious.  I usually get the vegetarian (avocado) on dutch crunch, or the roasted chicken w/avocado on dutch crunch or a sweet roll.  It's so good!  They make them with the right amount of everything.  And their side dishes are pretty good if you're trying to do a meal thing.  I like a few of the potato salads (potato and egg, creole potato salad) and a few of the pasta salads (mediterranean, pasta bianca).

And it's a grocery store so you can walk around and add chips, fruit, dessert, a drink, WHATEVER!

I wish they delivered.
author: Paz R.

description:
It is a grocery market. A very expensive grocery market for conventional food you can get anywhere. I wouldn't mind the prices so much if it was your friendly little neighborhood grocer, but it's not. Every time I run in for a quick jug of milk, eggs, or a little treat for my kids, the manager, Roy, is nothing short of surly.  I almost always regret going in there, yet because of  convenience I found myself falling into it's trap over the years.

I vow not to be seduced by it's close vicinity to my home ever again though. The last time I was there my 7yr old son accidentally  dropped a juice squeeze soda and it shattered on their floor before making it to the register. I apologized several times,and Roy just grumbled and went back and got the broom. I then went back and got another soda for my son, who looked all teary and kept saying sorry. I told him that everyone has accidents; that it's OK and we went  to the register. The girl just automatically swiped me for 3 sodas--without a word or explanation. She just took my money and I noticed after the fact, when I looked at my receipt, she charged me for the soda my little boy broke. I get it, you break it, you buy it, but really?? I mean at least they could have said something before they charged me. It was only a couple bucks, but an explanation that they have a certain shitty policy would be nice. I know it seems small, but after all these years of going there and paying their jacked prices, I can't t believe Arguello Market wouldn't eat one soda. The cashier-girl only shrugged and rolled her eyes a couple of times at me when I expressed that it was messed up. I asked Roy about it and he just scolded me. He said I need to watch my kid when he holds groceries. 
 .
 I don't know, again, a couple bucks seems petty, but  my son has always picked his little drink from the back and carried it to the register with no accidents--he's been a reg there since he was three. Well, he and I have decided together not to patronize this rude place again. We will make sure to go over to the new Whole Foods a few blocks away for our over priced, natural sodas. Now that I think about it, it will probably be cheaper there.
author: nancy s.

description: I will truly miss this place. We just moved from SF to St. Louis. This was our neighborhood store. Great sandwiches at their deli, friendly staff and quite the selection for a little supermarket.
author: Chuck F.

description:
So, 
This rating is for the Deli. 
I love the new improvements they have made. It is amazing what a little re-org can do for a place. They also added a soup bar with very tasty soup...

The Turkey Sandwich (duh) is totally amazing and addictive. 

The owner is really nice and feels like a real "neighborhood grocer," Friendly and helpful.

For the grocery part of the store I give it  3.5 stars. 
The reason is that they don't have much that is affordable here. Very difficult to get a loaf of bread for under $4.50, Even a tin of cookies is almost $7. Which is a bummer because I hate Safeway, and I don't like going all over town to different places to get what I need. I like this place, and if they could manage to make it a bit more affordable, I would shop there more. 

Also, if they would get some better organic meat, I would not have to treck all the way over to antonelli's. The Palo Alto based "organic" chicken they sell is the same stuff they sell at  whole foods... not good.

Replace it with "Mary's Chicken" and get the pastured kind and I am all over it.
Also, perhaps get an organic turkey alternative? I would pay a bit more.

If you live inthe inner richmond. Go to the deli. It rocks.
author: Andrea S.

description:
My friend brought me here, bragging about the fresh rotisserie chicken & turkey sandwiches, but when we got there they were all out.  After a hard workout, I was starving so I opted for the gigantic hot roast beef.  
It was loaded w/ provolone, lettuce, tomatoes, pickles, mustard and mayo. Yum!  I will definitely come back for the fresh rotisserie.

I wish I had a place like this in my neighborhood. They had affordable lunch meats & a bazillion types of side salads (creole potato salad, San Francisco potato salad are my friends favs).  They also have tamales and calzones for under $4!  Their produce was also affordable and looked really fresh.

Really, we need one of these markets in Russian Hill. Desperately!!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Nice neighborhood market, and a welcome reprieve from the Safeway on 7th and Cabrillo. Maybe not the best place to buy a huge cart full of groceries, but it's the ideal place to stop for a few items on the way home from work. In my experience, the store is clean and well stocked.

Bonus: Wide sidewalk with plenty of bike parking out front.
author: Mariah N.

description: Only tried the Pastrami, but it was delectable! From looking at other items, it's clear that everything they have is good. Will be going back soon!
author: Ryan M.

description:
GREATEST. TURKEY. SANDWICHES. EVER.

Seriously, turkey sammiches don't get any better than this.
author: Jae S.

description:
This is my neighborhood grocer. I love that I don't have to go to Safeway to get dinner fixings. They have just about everything you could need in a very quiet friendly atmosphere. 

Whenever I need help working on something at my apartment I can usually get help by offering to buy everyone Turkey Sandwiches! 

My only complaint would be that the wine selection lacks character. They definitely have a large selection but I tend to have a hard time finding something I want. 

No hassles, friendly staff, delicious sandwiches and a good selection.
author: Erin M.

description:
AMAZING SANDWICHES!!! My hangover cure is a hearty sandwich and i have found it at the arguello super market!! I got the pastrami on a sourdough roll, they heated the meat and cheese and their pickles are awesome as well!!
Very filling, i only ate half. Also we got the elbow macaroni salad and dipped some sweet onion kettle chips in it......SO GOOD.....

I did get to try a bite of the roast turkey from my friend, which was also very tasty. I saw the guy make it too, he literally just carved the meat right off a whole fucking turkey!!! badass.

LOVE this place. will be my new Sunday ritual!!
author: Susanna B.

description: It is so dangerous to have this place just a few blocks from my apartment.  Whenever I'm in need of a pick-me-up, I head over to Arguello Market.  They have an amazing selection of candy and ice cream, and just too much good food in general. Their turkey and rotisserie chicken sandwiches are also to die for. Such a great place!
author: Bridget B.

description: Good neighborhood market that's a block away from Golden Gate Park.  They make some pretty yummy sandwiches and sides that you can get for a picnic in the park.  For a small market, they surprisingly have a lot of products.  I can always find what I want.
author: Julie P.

description: When i went to go at USF, i would pretty much eat here all the time. The turkey sandwich are always fresh and so good. I would recommend the dark meat turkey sandwich to everyone, its really juicy and good. Parking is hard to find but well worth wait for the food.
author: Anthony V.

description:
Arguello Super, you are the best (well, next to a a., who was my benefactor on my last trip here!).

You had the super size cans of sugar free Red Bull which woke me up and caused me to be a complete lunatic for at least the next few hours. Note to self and everyone I care about....just like it is bad for you to super size at McDonald's, it is equally bad to super size a Red Bull. DON'T DO IT! 

okay, now that my public service announcement is over I will get back to my review. This little "corner market" is so much more. It truly is a small full service deli and grocery store. 

If you know me you know I get ideas in my head, and, sometimes, the more I think about them the more extravagant my ideas become. This creates a problem when I have about 10 minutes to get something done that is going to take an hour and I have 10 more last minute things to pick up to make everything "just right". 

This place has all of those last minute things when that idea has something to do with nachos and lots and lots of mixed drinks. Oh, and Red Bull, to give me the energy to keep on motorin'.......
author: Drue C.

description:
Take my word on this: making falafals in the waffle iron (fawaffles) is simply impossible. Made as directed, they will be too dry. Add eggs, milk, water, or butter (not necessarily in that order) and they will stick all over the inside of the waffle maker and will never ever set. If you plan a whole brunch around fawaffles and chicken fried bacon (brilliant idea, btw- if only those fawaffles would turn out), you will find your self surrounded by many hungry friends who have gone through just enough magnums of cheap champagne to turn on you and fry YOU up for brunch.

If you live in this neighborhood, you can easily divert that drunken energy and blood lust into a field trip to Arguello Market, where your friends can buy frozen hash browns, pita bread (for all that hummus that will NOT be smeared on fawaffles), assorted baked goods, fresh organic produce, more oil (it takes a lot of oil to make 2 dozen strips of chicken-fried bacon), gourmet cheeses,  high end crackers, and whatever else people who have been marathon-drinking since 8 a.m. care to eat by 1 in the afternoon. This place has it all! AND there's a deli case with delicious looking ready-made foods and deli meats and cheeses.

Thanks so much, Drue, for trying to make all of our dreams come true this weekend. Thanks so much, Arguello Market, for saving the day!

Oh, and P.S. Ed M LOOOOVES Peeps and this place carries them. If you're looking for the perfect gift for Ed M, Peeps are the way to go!!
author: Autumn K.

description: Sal is the owner and you can tell he takes great pride in his establishment. Yes, its all about the turkey, but the rest of the place has been slowly upgrading over the years. Perfect spot to pick up a picnic for the park or to set up a catering for your sales lunch.
author: Willis H.

description:
Best turkey sandwich in San Francisco.  Every time I go,  I hear other customers in line raving about how they drove across town to come here for the turkey sandwich.  As for the groceries, they have beautiful produce, a nice selection of specialty or ethnic items, and very friendly service. (A friend of mine came up short on cash at the register one day and they waived the $.30 cents he was missing.  Who does that any more?!)  They even started selling Kombucha recently, which I love.  There is a Safeway 6 blocks away, but I often end up at Arguello Super because it feels like "my" local grocery store and they carry items that Safeway doesn't.  

The place is a little pricey, but it's an independent neighborhood grocery store -- very much worth paying the extra money to patronize it.
author: Gaping F.

description:
Despite this store being small, I was always able to get mostly what I needed here. The food they do stock is really good stuff. They have the most delicious hummus here that you should try.

Deli is awesome as well with good, fresh meat and variety. The staff was always nice as well. The only disadvantage is that they only take Visa/MC and obviously some things are priced higher than you would see elsewhere.

I still haven't found a neighborhood market as good as this one. It makes me wish I still lived in the area! It's not the end-all market that you must visit, but if you live in the 'hood it's awesome.
author: Ryan V.

description: All I have to say is: Fresh Turkey sandwich on a wheat roll with all the fixings and cheddar cheese. One of the best sandwiches I've ever eaten.  That's all.
author: Matt J.

description: The only thing I come here to get is their infamous TURKEY SANDWICH (dutch crunch bread, dark meat, avocado, mayo and swiss cheese)...I prefer dark meat because its less dry, but you may get some bits of tendon/bones here and there. They do charge extra for cheese ($.60 I believe) but it is well worth it. There are random days when I sit and home and salivate over the thought of getting one of these sandwiches. For under $7, it is a PRETTY GOOD DEAL!
author: Nancy Y.

description:
Chicken + Dutch Crunch = Sandwich
Sandwich + Drink = Meal
Meal + Mouth = Delicious
Full Stomach = Happy

*Hints* 
-World Famous (a little pretentious but not far off) chicken sandwich order it hot.
-Support local establishments keeps the neighborhood feel alive.

I'd come back here again.
author: Po L.

description:
For a supermarket it has the essentials, but truthfully whats so magnanimous about it is the sandwiches.

Which is why all other people who give good ratings talk about the sandwiches. Cause I too love the sandwiches here!

The service is wonderful and they are friendly, I became friends with a lot of the workers there. 

I used to live right around the corner from this place and loved getting the fresh rotisserie turkey sandwiches with dutch crunch bread.
For the turkey you can pick white or dark meat. put cranberries in if you choose, avocado, salt and pepper, cheese etc.
The other sandwiches are good too. (my bf loves the cornbeef sandwiches)

(Although on rare occasions the bread tasted weird and the sandwiches weren't as great, but that only happened to me once or twice)
author: Michelle L.

description:
I've only started coming here regularly since Cala Foods on Geary & 4th closed down about two years ago. This is the only decent deli nearby RCTVHQ, so I was essentially forced to come here by default. What I discovered is the fresh roasted turkey sandwiches are The Best in the City.

Don't believe me? It says so right on the canopy outside!

All kidding aside, they really are pretty addictive. I was craving one just now and slid by to get my fix. I justified it by picking up a couple grocery items while there.

While some stuff can be pricey, it is possible to find stuff that is comparable (if not slightly less than) Safeway or any other big market. I avoid the produce completely, however. It's way cheaper to drop by the 4th & Geary Farmer's Market. So, they lose a star there.

The rest of the deli items are all decently priced, actually, and a freshly made sandwich averages about $5 (fresh turkey is slightly higher). The meats are all good quality, though.

If it were a bit closer, open later and maybe a tad less expensive in certain things, it'd get a bump up. But don't let that keep anyone from grabbing a turkey-sammy while in the hood...
author: ACE A.

description:
I couldn't be happier to have this wonderful market in my neighborhood.  Arguello on a whole is amazingly consistent.  Every now and then they might run out of something, but rarely do they not have a substitute item available.  

The deli is great as well.  All you need to know is that this is where the mayor purportedly buys his turkey sandwiches.  The produce department (especially vegetables) has improved greatly in the last months.  Beer and wine selection is solid for a store of this size.  

Most importantly, the owner seems to really care about his store and the neighborhood.  The areas surrounding the store are almost always clean, and there is always an improvement project of some sort going on (see the beautiful new glowing awnings and signage).  Arguello Super Market is a great asset to the Inner Rich.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Who knew that the "WORLD FAMOUS TURKEY SANDWICH" can be found in a supermarket?  Here's the shpiel:- Their delicious dutch crunch roll was obviously fresh with a crispy , cracked toasted top  tasting like a dense brioche bread.  The turkey meat was picked off the 'straight-out-of-the-rotisserie'  roasted turkey (yup imagine your grandma's bird on Thanksgiving with its sole purpose: to  make this hearty sandwich).  All the fixins including cranberry jam were included.  
Furnish your meal with Kettle chips (Salt and Pepper for me) around the corner and drinks along the end of the grocery (Orangina for me).
Oh don't forget the side dishes from pasta salads to greek spanakopita.  I tried their Potato Salad- which tasted as if it was half an egg salad as well.  Rich, Creamy Mayonnaise seasoned with italian parsley, scallions and paprika and just enough mustard..(this was an additional 1 star).

PS- You can also order your Thanksgiving turkey here :-)

UPDATE: 11/29/07
They have 3 different types of Potato Salad ( The one I had was half Egg Salad).  VERY GOOD :-)
author: Arissa C.

description:
I have to say something about this place.

It is the ultimate neighborhood grocery store! First of all, my friend lives a block away, and after spending the night at her house, she wanted to get breakfast at the store "down the street."

We walk into this store and instantly, the owner spots my friend, walks up to her and gives her a hi-five! 

Then, the guy working behind the deli counter raises his tongs at her, and points to one of the many muffins on display in front of him. She picks out the ONLY chocolate muffin (grrrr..) which left me to pick my "plan B" muffin, banana nut. 

All I can say is..mmmmm. So good!

We then walk over to the beautiful and colorful assortment of fruit that was laid out RIGHT BEFORE the checkout cashier.  Who could resist?

 Smart. Very smart...

Walking out with my muffin, an orange, a Fuji apple and a smile, I felt like this was my neighborhood store too. The personable service that we received (my friend says that they are like this all of the time) very much resembled a small town grocery store, which is very hard, if not rare to find in a city such as SF.

This place totally made my morning. I'm now a fan and I'm definitely coming back.
author: First C.

description:
They have the biggest, best sandwiches EVER.  Hands down.  I don't care what anyone else thinks :)

The meat is carved right in front of you and practically heaped onto bread with anything you can ask for.  A good sandwich should be a like a well rounded meal barely contained by two slices of bread, and that's definitely what you'll get at the Arguello Market.

And besides, who could resist anything that creates this kind of enthusiasm? errr...fervor maybe?  (watch the video and you be the judge)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fQ75WHwgyU

(Seriously...that is actually one of my good friends freaking out about the rotisserie at Arguello Market.)
author: Stefanie B.

description: Roasted Turkey Sandwich do it! If you don't you must be a vegetarian.
author: Eddie T.

description:
Something about the wind got Holly chatty. 
Maybe it was her jaw clenching to the cold, her hair jostling in the wind that got her so jumpy. 

I was calm. 
At the market down the street, us girls walked through the isles looking for toothpaste, cheese, and crackers. 

"I can't find your hippy toothpaste," Holly said holding her arms while I cracked my knuckles.
"Hippy?" I asked.
"That all natural, no sugar, no coloring, no preservative, eco shit," and continued, "excuse my language. It's damn cold."

I guess she was cranky too. Skipping around, twirling and pissed off by the wind that gyrated her limbs in odd funny ways. I mistook her energy as whimsy or silliness. 

The market was brightly lit. Outside the sun was about to come down. To me an orange sunset is good luck.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Very convenient, so I don't gripe too much about the prices. 
The sandwiches are very good! Get one on Dutch Crunch and you'll thank me later. 
One thing that bugs me is that you have to spend $10 or more to use an ATM. Also they refuse to give me even a dollar in quarters for change.  A little strict on their cashier rules, but hey, they sell Muni passes. 
I wish they would stay open just a little later, too. closing at 8:30pm on Saturday just doesn't fit into my schedule. ;)
author: joanna r.

description:
So psyched to have this market just blocks away from my house and on the way home from work! Reasons why I love this place:
* Decent selection of produce and cheeses (local cheese made in Marin). 
* They have many of the random ingredients I need when I get in my crazy compulsive baking mode (including cupcake liners!). 
* It's the closest place to me that has monthly MUNI pass (thank you for taking my commuter check!). 
* Now that ghetto-Safeway on 7th Ave is gone, this is a decent neighborhood alternative for an alcohol run.

I'm going to head there right now to buy a Mega Millions lottery ticket that will hopefully save me from the 10th Circle of Hell known as Student Loan Debt.
author: Steph P.

description: According to their in-store sign, this is the "Home of the famous Turkey Sandwich!" I've had the Veggie Sandwich and recently I decided to try the Turkey Sandwich. Veggie Sandwich is not that great compared to other places I've tried (Royal Ground and Lou's Cafe). It was really bland and... boring? You can tell the Turkey Sandwich is made with good quality ingredients because they roast the turkey in-house and the meat is really tender and juicy (think dark meat). I did like my Turkey Sandwich, but I think this place is still a little overrated. It's also a little pricey - sandwiches are around $7-$8. They have all the ingredients right, but once again the sandwiches are too bland and basic for my taste. Throw in some sauce or spread or somethin'! The sandwiches could use more flavor, that's all.
author: Linda T.

description: great sandwiches and sweets selection - perfect place to grab lunch and head into GGP.
author: Jenn D.

description:
Like everyone here says... the hot turkey sandwiches are fantastic.  My favorite combo... everything with cheddar on dutch crunch.  Yum!

I can't tell you how many times I decided to buy lunch there.  I go so often not because I'm too lazy to make it myself (well, maybe).  I go because the sandwiches are just that good.  If you live in the area, you're lucky.  If you happen to be in the area and need to get lunch, try it. 

Plus it's a fantastic grocery too.  It'll have just about everything you need if you live closeby.  I admit, I go to a supermarket chain for most of my shopping.  But when I forget this or that, whatever I need is always there.
author: Ben C.

description:
Last weekend my boyfriend informed me it's 'physically wrong' to eat one of their giant turkey sandwiches (on a dutch crunch, with mayo, lettuce, tomato, cranberry and avocado) in one sitting and not pass out into a (heavenly) food coma for the next 3 days. 

Well, I certainly showed him up, and ate 2 - one on Saturday, then a repeat visit on Sunday. I was even tempted to eat his extra half that was sitting idle in the fridge for more than 10 minutes. 

Part of me is ecstatic that this sensational turkey sandwich making machine is less than a block away from my house, but part of me is a little scared. I can see a growing addiction, and need to make every sandwich live up to this one here. 

With all the fixings (namely the cranberry and avocado exploding out of the sides) it's about an $8 sandwich...but it's worth every penny. Just wish the grocery store carried a few limes and maybe those spicy string beans to craft the perfect Bloody Mary beverage to accompany the turkey sandos on the weekends.
author: Kelly R.

description:
I always get the roasted turkey sandwich on a wheat roll with pepperjack cheese and everything on it. The bread is always fresh and soft. The turkey is to die for. They aren't lying about the turkey sandwich being WORLD FAMOUS. It's absolutely delicious.

Overall, you won't be disappointed ordering any sandwich you get from their deli. The potato salads are tasty too.

The owner is nice. Most of the employees are friendly and always greet with a smiling face. There's one in particular, (jsut in case you run into him he looks similar to Mario/Luigi), he was rude to me at the cashier when I politely asked for change for a $5. He was very snappy and irritated and quickly snapped, "NO!"

Jeez.
author: upper d.

description:
The place is a bit expensive but thats what you pay for if you want convenience. The selection isnt great. 

this place is good for fruit.

I tried to buy a loaf of bread and some crackers and the dude just stared at me because I had a debit card. then he said "sorry you have to buy more stuff to use your card" I just walked out.  

location is great but not worth the hassel. Go to safeway and save some money
author: Danny G.

description:
Um, so yeah, I've never had a better turkey sandwich in my life. This isn't some half-assed turkey, this is Thanksgiving-turkey-style that they're rotissierie-ing every half hour or so. When do you EVER go to a deli and they ask, "White meat or dark meat"???

Perfect meal either before a big night out on the town, or the following afternoon when you're hungover as hell. You just cannot go wrong with this place - it kept me going for a good year or two in college. But if you're getting booze here, be aware - it closes at 8pm. I've been burned more than once by that...
author: Drew S.

description: Arguello Supermarket you never disappointment.  This review isn't really for the supermarket itself its for the deli counter.   I work up at USF and eating in the neighborhood....eh, not the best selection but then I discovered Arguello.  They make our sandwiches on Saturdays when I am stuck working finals.  Its comes in a nice plastic container with a side salad (fruit, potato, veggie, pasta or macaroni), an orange slice and a cookie.  I'm like a toddler, hand me a cookie and everything was 100 times better than it was 20 seconds ago.  Their tuna sandwiches are nice and non-tunay, they use real turkey breast, the roast beef is nice and red and the chicken salad is yummy as well.  The prices are also very reasonable.
author: Kristin Marie S.

description:
This place makes amazing sandos.  Really quite amazing.  Mine is a vegi on sourdough, no mayo, with mozzarella and pepperoncinies.  Total cost: $4.49 (this is not a typo--it's that cheap).  

As people below have mentioned, the line around lunch is sometimes rather long so, take a break around 11 and grab a sando to go (and let it hangout for a bit while you get hungry), or show up a little late (you know, all those old tricks).  

But if you like the roasted turkey (yeah, I don't eat the dead animals) then you'd better show up before 2 or 3 because by then they tend to be out of warm, fresh, dead bird.

On to the Supermarket aspect: meh -- it's got some stuff at decent prices, and some stuff absurdly overpriced.  Nothing new or amazing here -- it's just your standard Mini-Supermarket.
author: jack p.

description:
Arguello Market seems to be a favorite of the locals living in the area.  Every time I walk into the store, it seems as if some people are doing major grocery shopping.  Which is insane, considering the high prices that the store charges on basic juices and fruits.  

But it's understandable- they are a mom and pop store, trying to survive smack in the middle of a newly renovated Safeway and Lucky's down the street.  

Here are their strong points:
1.  Turkey Sandwiches- the best in the city.  Be sure to get it on dutch crunch bread (seems as if everybody knows this secret already!) and with avocados.  mmmmmmmm!

2.  Violet Crumble Candy Bars- Couldn't find these anywhere else in the city but Arguello Market. (update- they've been out of stock for awhile, but they sporadically have them.)

3.  Tom's Cookies Take Home Dough- enough said.

4.  Also, check out the baked good assortment right in front of the check out counter.  You are sure to be pleased:)
author: Clarissa P.

description:
I love Arguello Super's rotisserie turkey sandwiches like a baby loves his mama's milk. After a long day of surfing or a long night of drinking you can be sure to find me hitting up this run of the mill corner store for aforesaid sandwich. 

They are constantly cooking a fresh turkey (they must go through 10 a day) and they carve it straight off the carcass for your sandwich. You get to specify white or dark meat (nothing beats tender, juicy dark) along with the bread and accouterments. 

The sandwich costs about $7, but it is well worth it. Sometimes if I'm here around lunch time, I buy a second sandwich for dinner. Yes I am addicted. I want one right now. My hand is shaking. I need it.

Otherwise, they have beer, wine, some produce, but everything is overpriced.  Enjoy!
author: Thor M.

description:
Maybe I just caught them on a bad day.  Maybe I had a sour look on my face that the guy behind the counter was responding to.  Maybe he made me a crappy sandwich cause i looked like a jerk.

But a bunch of sandwich ingredients piled haphazardly between two pieces of bread do not a sandwich make.  I appreciate the effort with the freshly-roasted turkey, but that's only pays off if it's less dry than the turkey my uncle makes; last Passover he put the bird BACK IN the oven because it wasn't dry enough for his taste.  

However, you can still make a decent sandwich with dry turkey.  We've all done it.  Apparently Arguello Market hasn't.  

Ways to make a sandwich with dry turkey taste even worse, as demonstrated by AM:

-make it on overly-thick slices of bread that drown out any of the other flavors
-spread the mayonnaise so thin that you don't notice it's there
-apply so little of the cranberry spread (that I paid extra for) that you don't notice its presence either
-add too much lettuce, of which there should only be enough to add crisp texture, not so much that the wateriness washes away the remnants of taste left in your mouth
-use underripe tomatoes.

Now at least one of these issues has afflicted most every sandwich i've ever eaten that i didn't make for myself, most frequently the usage of underripe tomatoes.  But all of them in combination render nothing more than a dry (and thereby difficult and unpleasant to eat) and utterly crappy sandwich.  Add to that the fact that the guy working the deli counter was entirely unfriendly and the stupid thing costs something like $8.75.  AND you have to walk through the store in a roundabout way to pay at the register, a cheap gift store trick that encourages you to buy more things.

Sorry everybody, I just don't get it.  I'll stick to Roxie's

Two stars because I can't bear to give a small, local, non-chain market that puts pickles on its sandwiches one star.  It's really one and a half stars that i rounded up because i'm trying not to hold it against the place that i can't figure out why everyone likes the carelessly constructed, miserable excuse for a sandwich.
author: Ben S.

description:
Summary (sandwich): Tasteless, thin Turkey sandwich and ambivalent service...no thanks!

(Disclaimer that I've only been here once, for the Turkey sandwich, after seeing it listed on SFGate as "10 best", so this review is just about the one sandwich and experience.)

That said, I've had some bland turkey in my time, but this takes the cake.  You'd think that adding cheese, onions, mayo, pepper, etc. would help, but this must be some special black hole turkey into which all taste and flavor gets sucked into an alternate universe.  Complement the bland with there not being enough meat to cover the roll.  Oh, "service"...same black hole as the flavor: Dude had to ask three times which cheese I requested, no eye contact, slide the sandwich bag across the top of the counter (no "here ya go" or "thanks", or whatever).

Thumbs down for the food, the service, and for whatever unschooled sandwich eater put this on the SFGate's "10 best" sandwich list.
author: Steve E.

description: Great sandwiches (even have fresh roasted turkey), good coffee, and friendly owner. They have a deli and it is also a grocery store with lots of items to choose from.
author: Miles W.

description:
I like almost across the street from Arguello Supermarket. I've been going since I was a little kid (so about almot 20 years). They've really re-vamped the place up over the years. This place is sturdy...a lil pricey on the necessary items i need to purchase, but hey...it's a neighborhood grocery store and u can't compete with safeway or those big chain supermarkets.

The sandwiches here are really good. which ever one you get, get it on Dutch Crunch. it just makes everything better. If your looking for a recommendation, get their turkey or chicken sandwiches b/c they roast them fresh on the premises. If you have $10 to spend on lunch, i suggest here.
author: Ivy L.

description: I just dropped over $50 bucks at this expensive little market and the guy at checkout made me pay for 2 paper cups that I wanted for our picnic. I love to support local business, but geez way to turn off a customer.
author: Suzanne G.

description:
I just got back from the perfect lunch. After finding the listing in Yelp I took a walk with the girlfriend down to the Arguello Super Market. We ordered 2 fresh turkey sandwich (with cranberry on Dutch Crunch) boxed lunches. 

Walk a couple blocks south to the Conservatory of Flowers. Found a nice bench and proceeded to eat the best turkey sandwich in the city. It was so delicious a little black dog that was fascinated running around the park picked up the scent and came over for a bite.

I'm so happy to live in between two fabulous sandwich shops - Blue Front on Haight and Arguello Super Market. Delicious!
author: keith h.

description:
Ok, first I must address Natasha T's review down there.  It's not a $10 minimum for a credit card purchase.  It's a $10 minimum or $1 additional charge.  They are a small store.  Mastercard charges them to use the credit card service, so they have to either have a minimum purchase or a small fee if it's less than $10.  Also, I've shopped here literally 2-4 times a week for almost three years.  I have NEVER seen anyone there be rude.  As a matter of fact, it's been the same five employees the entire time I've lived in this neighborhood and they are all nice.  

I lived literally on top of this grocery store for a while now.  They have never been anything but nice to me, my roommates and everyone I've known who has shopped there.  They have great turkey sandwiches and homemade soups.   Several times, I've had to ask where something is and I've never been yelled at.  (Jeez, really some exageration on yelp sometimes!  The man with the moustache is named Roy and I can't imagine him yelling at anyone unless they were yelling from the back of the store and he yelled back because he couldn't leave the register!)  They have always been kind and courteous.  A cab drove into their front window around a year ago... they were even good natured about that!  A big hole in their store in the middle of the rainy winter and they were nothing but nice to people!  Crazy!  

Other than that, it's amazingly convenient.  I've rarely gone to the store when they didn't have what I was looking for.  If I ask for something and they don't have it, the owner normally orders it so next time I need it, it's there.  They even sell MUNI passes and stamps!  

This is a great little place, with wonderful people working there.  Not to mention the BEST turkey sandwiches in the City.  :)
author: Corey F.

description:
Arguello Super is a small local market stocked with all the basic items you would need. The actually have a good deli and selection of produce. This is a super market and not a convenience store. Parking is nonexistent and you are going to pay more than Cala or Vons. 

I often wondered how the market stays open but there is always people coming and going through it. If you are local without a car or lazy then this place is close and will have what you are looking for or an alternative. 

As a side note, if you are picnicing in Golden Gate Park, this is a good place to stop to pick up lunch.
author: Lance H.

description:
This review is for the roasted turkey sandwiches.

I LOVE THEM!

This place is perfect for the following:

-hangover cure
-sunny golden gate park lunch
-just cuz you're hungry

The turkey is 100% fresh and the sandwiches are bombbbb.  I have to say that they have messed up my order a few times, but the sandwich is so good it REALLY doesn't matter all that much.
author: Jules G.

description: Best neighborhood market in SF. They have everything, including a first class deli.
author: David B.

description:
This is a small market that feels like a hybrid between a supermarket and a 7-11. This means that their selection is larger than a normal corner store and that the prices are higher than at (say) Safeway. Overall it's a nice little store that also happens to be a deli that sells some good sandwiches.

I wouldn't go as far as to call the turkey sandwich "world famous", but it's quite good nevertheless. If you're going to the park for a walk and need a bite on the way, then it's definitely worth to drop by. If you're a local, you already know about this place and you know that the sandwiches are a good lunch deal.

The grocery part of the store is, well, a grocery :)
author: Dumitru E.

description:
One of my students begged me to get sandwiches from Arguello Super Market for a staff lunch. I wanted Pita Pit. She convinced me that Arguello Super was far...Superior (hee hee).

I got a turkey sandwich with swiss, lettuce, extra pickles, and extra mustard on wheat. When I unwrapped it, it was a bit soggy but that could have been because we picked up our order an hour before the lunch began.

Overall, this place is good- especially when my work account pays for it!
author: Kayla N.

description: I finally tried the turkey sandwich. I found it bland and lacking something to make it at all memorable. Maybe mine was missing something. They promised pickles but I also did not get any. The bread was on the sweet side for me and I ended up taking the top off.
author: Susan M.

description:
This review is about their deli. And the missing star is because the supermarket part is generally over priced yet decently stocked for a small place. 

This deli is a usual saturday or sunday stop for lunch. Sandwiches, chips, and drinks and off to golden gate park. There is usually a line at the deli, which is a good sign of things to come, so you generally have to wait a bit.
